href="./Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a><sup about="#mwt183" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-17" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"earth_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwbg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwbw">[3]</span></a></sup></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p id="mwcA"><b id="mwcQ">Earth</b> is the third <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planet" title="Planet" id="mwcg">planet</a> from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sun" title="Sun" id="mwcw">Sun</a> and the only <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Astronomical_object" title="Astronomical object" id="mwdA">astronomical object</a> known to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_habitability" title="Planetary habitability" id="mwdQ">harbor</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Life" title="Life" id="mwdg">life</a>. This is enabled by Earth being a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_world" title="Ocean world" id="mwdw">water world</a>, the only one in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mweA">Solar System</a> sustaining liquid surface water. Almost all of Earth's water is contained in its global <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean" title="Ocean" id="mweQ">ocean</a>, covering <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_distribution_on_Earth" title="Water distribution on Earth" id="mweg">70.8%</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwew">Earth's crust</a>. The remaining 29.2% of Earth's crust is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land" title="Land" id="mwfA">land</a>, most of which is located in the form of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continent" title="Continent" id="mwfQ">continental</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Landmass" title="Landmass" id="mwfg">landmasses</a> within one <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hemispheres_of_Earth" title="Hemispheres of Earth" id="mwfw">hemisphere</a>, Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land_hemisphere" title="Land hemisphere" class="mw-redirect" id="mwgA">land hemisphere</a>. Most of Earth's land is somewhat <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Humid" title="Humid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwgQ">humid</a> and covered by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vegetation" title="Vegetation" id="mwgg">vegetation</a>, while large <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet" id="mwgw">sheets of ice</a> at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_polar_regions" title="Earth's polar regions" class="mw-redirect" id="mwhA">Earth's polar</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Desert" title="Desert" id="mwhQ">deserts</a> retain more water than Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Groundwater" title="Groundwater" id="mwhg">groundwater</a>, lakes, rivers and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_vapor#In_Earth's_atmosphere" title="Water vapor" id="mwhw">atmospheric water</a> combined. Earth's crust consists of slowly moving <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics" id="mwiA">tectonic plates</a>, which interact to produce mountain ranges, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Volcano" title="Volcano" id="mwiQ">volcanoes</a>, and earthquakes. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_outer_core" title="Earth's outer core" id="mwig">Earth has a liquid outer core</a> that generates a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magnetosphere" title="Magnetosphere" id="mwiw">magnetosphere</a> capable of deflecting most of the destructive <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_wind" title="Solar wind" id="mwjA">solar winds</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cosmic_radiation" title="Cosmic radiation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwjQ">cosmic radiation</a>.</p>

<p id="mwjg">Earth has <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth" id="mwjw">a dynamic atmosphere</a>, which sustains Earth's surface conditions and protects it from most <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meteoroid" title="Meteoroid" id="mwkA">meteoroids</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ozone_layer" title="Ozone layer" id="mwkQ">UV-light at entry</a>. It has a composition of primarily <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen" id="mwkg">nitrogen</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxygen" title="Oxygen" id="mwkw">oxygen</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_vapor" title="Water vapor" id="mwlA">Water vapor</a> is widely present in the atmosphere, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloud#Formation" title="Cloud" id="mwlQ">forming clouds</a> that cover most of the planet. The water vapor acts as a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas" id="mwlg">greenhouse gas</a> and, together with other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, particularly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide" id="mwlw">carbon dioxide</a> (CO<sub id="mwmA">2</sub>), creates the conditions for both liquid surface water and water vapor to persist via the capturing of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_irradiance" title="Solar irradiance" id="mwmQ">energy from the Sun's light</a>. This process maintains the current average surface temperature of 14.76<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwmg">Â </span>Â°C, at which water is liquid under atmospheric pressure. Differences in the amount of captured energy between geographic regions (as with the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Equatorial_region" title="Equatorial region" class="mw-redirect" id="mwmw">equatorial region</a> receiving more sunlight than the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_regions" title="Polar regions" class="mw-redirect" id="mwnA">polar regions</a>) drive <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmospheric_circulation" title="Atmospheric circulation" id="mwnQ">atmospheric</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_current" title="Ocean current" id="mwng">ocean currents</a>, producing a global <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Climate_system" title="Climate system" id="mwnw">climate system</a> with different <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Climate_region" title="Climate region" class="mw-redirect" id="mwoA">climate regions</a>, and a range of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weather" title="Weather" id="mwoQ">weather</a> phenomena such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Precipitation" title="Precipitation" id="mwog">precipitation</a>, allowing components such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nitrogen_cycle" title="Nitrogen cycle" id="mwow">nitrogen</a> to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biogeochemical_cycle" title="Biogeochemical cycle" id="mwpA">cycle</a>.</p>

<p id="mwpQ">Earth is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrostatic_equilibrium" title="Hydrostatic equilibrium" id="mwpg">rounded</a> into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_ellipsoid" title="Earth ellipsoid" id="mwpw">an ellipsoid</a> with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_circumference" title="Earth's circumference" id="mwqA">a circumference</a> of about 40,000<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwqQ">Â </span>km. It is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_Solar_System_objects_by_size" title="List of Solar System objects by size" id="mwqg">densest planet in the Solar System</a>. Of the four <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet" id="mwqw">rocky planets</a>, it is the largest and most massive. Earth is about eight <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Light-minute" title="Light-minute" class="mw-redirect" id="mwrA">light-minutes</a> away from the Sun and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_orbit" title="Earth's orbit" id="mwrQ">orbits it</a>, taking a year (about 365.25 days) to complete one revolution. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_rotation" title="Earth's rotation" id="mwrg">Earth rotates</a> around its own axis in slightly less than a day (in about 23 hours and 56 minutes). <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth#Axial_tilt_and_seasons" id="mwrw">Earth's axis of rotation</a> is tilted with respect to the perpendicular to its orbital plane around the Sun, producing seasons. Earth is orbited by one <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Claimed_moons_of_Earth" title="Claimed moons of Earth" id="mwsA">permanent</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite" id="mwsQ">natural satellite</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Moon" title="Moon" id="mwsg">Moon</a>, which orbits Earth at 384,400<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwsw">Â </span>km (1.28 light seconds) and is roughly a quarter as wide as Earth. Through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tidal_locking" title="Tidal locking" id="mwtA">tidal locking</a>, the Moon always faces Earth with the same side, which causes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tide" title="Tide" id="mwtQ">tides</a>, stabilizes Earth's axis, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tidal_acceleration" title="Tidal acceleration" id="mwtg">gradually slows its rotation</a>.</p>

<p id="mwtw">Earth, like most other bodies in the Solar System, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Age_of_Earth" title="Age of Earth" id="mwuA">formed 4.5 billion years ago</a> from gas in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Formation_and_evolution_of_the_Solar_System" title="Formation and evolution of the Solar System" id="mwuQ">early Solar System</a>. During the first <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Billion_years" title="Billion years" class="mw-redirect" id="mwug">billion years</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_Earth" title="History of Earth" id="mwuw">Earth's history</a>, the ocean formed and then <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abiogenesis" title="Abiogenesis" id="mwvA">life developed</a> within it. Life spread globally and has been altering Earth's atmosphere and surface, leading to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Great_Oxidation_Event" title="Great Oxidation Event" id="mwvQ">Great Oxidation Event</a> two billion years ago. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human" title="Human" id="mwvg">Humans</a> emerged 300,000 years ago in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Africa" title="Africa" id="mwvw">Africa</a> and have spread across every continent on Earth with the exception of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwwA">Antarctica</a>. Humans depend on Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biosphere" title="Biosphere" id="mwwQ">biosphere</a> and natural resources for their survival, but have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment" id="mwwg">increasingly impacted the planet's environment</a>. Humanity's current impact on Earth's climate and biosphere is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sustainability" title="Sustainability" id="mwww">unsustainable</a>, threatening the livelihood of humans and many other forms of life, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction" id="mwxA">causing widespread extinctions</a>.<sup about="#mwt188" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-27" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-27"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-27" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 23;" id="mwxQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwxg">[23]</span></a></sup></p>

<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" data-mw='{"autoGenerated":true}' id="mwxw"/></section><section data-mw-section-id="1" id="mwyA"><h2 id="Etymology">Etymology</h2>
<p id="mwyQ">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Modern_English" title="Modern English" id="mwyg">Modern English</a> word <span class="anchor" id="Name" about="#mwt191" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"anchor","href":"./Template:Anchor"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Name"},"2":{"wt":"Etymology"}},"i":0}}]}'></span><span class="anchor" id="mwyw" about="#mwt191"></span> <i id="mwzA">Earth</i> developed, via <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_English" title="Middle English" id="mwzQ">Middle English</a>, from an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Old_English" title="Old English" id="mwzg">Old English</a> noun most often spelled <i id="mwzw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/eorÃ°e" title="wikt:eorÃ°e" about="#mwt192" typeof="mw:Transclusion" class="extiw" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"linktext","href":"./Template:Linktext"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"eorÃ°e"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw0A">eorÃ°e</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt198" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-oedearth_28-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"oedearth"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-oedearth-28"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-oedearth-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 24;" id="mw0Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw0g">[24]</span></a></sup> It has cognates in every <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages" id="mw0w">Germanic language</a>, and their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Proto-Germanic" title="Proto-Germanic" class="mw-redirect" id="mw1A">ancestral root</a> has been reconstructed as <a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Proto-Germanic/erÃ¾Å" title="wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/erÃ¾Å" class="extiw" id="mw1Q">*<i id="mw1g">erÃ¾Å</i></a>. In its earliest attestation, the word <i id="mw1w">eorÃ°e</i> was already being used to translate the many senses of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect" id="mw2A">Latin</a> <i id="mw2Q"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/terra" title="wikt:terra" about="#mwt193" typeof="mw:Transclusion" class="extiw" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"linktext","href":"./Template:Linktext"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"terra"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw2g">terra</a></i> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language" class="mw-redirect" id="mw2w">Greek</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Î³á¿†" title="wikt:Î³á¿†" about="#mwt194" typeof="mw:Transclusion" class="extiw" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"linktext","href":"./Template:Linktext"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Î³á¿†"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw3A">Î³á¿†</a> <i id="mw3Q">gÄ“</i>: the ground, its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soil" title="Soil" id="mw3g">soil</a>, dry land, the human world, the surface of the world (including the sea), and the globe itself. As with Roman <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terra_(goddess)" title="Terra (goddess)" class="mw-redirect" id="mw3w">Terra</a>/TellÅ«s and Greek <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gaia_(goddess)" title="Gaia (goddess)" class="mw-redirect" id="mw4A">Gaia</a>, Earth may have been a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_goddess" title="Earth goddess" class="mw-redirect" id="mw4Q">personified goddess</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Germanic_religion_(aboriginal)" title="Germanic religion (aboriginal)" class="mw-redirect" id="mw4g">Germanic paganism</a>: late <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Norse_mythology" title="Norse mythology" id="mw4w">Norse mythology</a> included <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./JÃ¶rÃ°" title="JÃ¶rÃ°" id="mw5A">JÃ¶rÃ°</a> ('Earth'), a giantess often given as the mother of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thor" title="Thor" id="mw5Q">Thor</a>.<sup about="#mwt202" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-29" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-29"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-29" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mw5g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw5w">[25]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mw6A">Historically, <i id="mw6Q">earth</i> has been written in lowercase. From <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Middle_English" title="Early Middle English" class="mw-redirect" id="mw6g">early Middle English</a>, its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Definite_article" title="Definite article" class="mw-redirect" id="mw6w">definite sense</a> as "the globe" was expressed as <i id="mw7A">the</i> earth. By the era of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Modern_English" title="Early Modern English" id="mw7Q">Early Modern English</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Capitalization_in_English#History_of_English_capitalization" title="Capitalization in English" id="mw7g">capitalization of nouns began to prevail</a>, and <i id="mw7w">the earth</i> was also written <i id="mw8A">the Earth</i>, particularly when referenced along with other heavenly bodies. More recently, the name is sometimes simply given as <i id="mw8Q">Earth</i>, by analogy with the names of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mw8g">other planets</a>, though <i id="mw8w">earth</i> and forms with <i id="mw9A">the</i> remain common.<sup about="#mwt205" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-oedearth_28-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"oedearth"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-oedearth-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 24;" id="mw9Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw9g">[24]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Style_guide" title="Style guide" id="mw9w">House styles</a> now vary: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxford_spelling" title="Oxford spelling" id="mw-A">Oxford spelling</a> recognizes the lowercase form as the most common, with the capitalized form an acceptable variant. Another convention capitalizes "Earth" when appearing as a name (for example, "Earth's atmosphere") but writes it in lowercase when preceded by <i id="mw-Q">the</i> (for example, "the atmosphere of the earth"). It almost always appears in lowercase in colloquial expressions such as "what on earth are you doing?"<sup about="#mwt209" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-30" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-30"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-30" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mw-g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw-w">[26]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mw_A">Occasionally, the name <i id="mw_Q">Terra</i> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt213" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"2":{"wt":"t"},"3":{"wt":"É›r"},"4":{"wt":"É™"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw_g"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É›r/: 'err' in 'merry'">É›r</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span></span>/</a></span></span> is used in scientific writing and especially in science fiction to distinguish humanity's inhabited planet from others,<sup about="#mwt226" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-31" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-31"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-31" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mw_w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQA">[27]</span></a></sup> while in poetry <i id="mwAQE">Tellus</i> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt214" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"2":{"wt":"t"},"3":{"wt":"É›"},"4":{"wt":"l"},"5":{"wt":"É™"},"6":{"wt":"s"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAQI"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É›/: 'e' in 'dress'">É›</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span> has been used to denote personification of the Earth.<sup about="#mwt230" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-32" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-32"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-32" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 28;" id="mwAQM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQQ">[28]</span></a></sup> <i id="mwAQU">Terra</i> is also the name of the planet in some <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Romance_languages" title="Romance languages" id="mwAQY">Romance languages</a> (languages that evolved from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAQc">Latin</a>) like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Italian_language" title="Italian language" id="mwAQg">Italian</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language" id="mwAQk">Portuguese</a>, while in other Romance languages the word gave rise to names with slightly altered spellings (like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spanish_language" title="Spanish language" id="mwAQo">Spanish</a> <i id="mwAQs">Tierra</i> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./French_language" title="French language" id="mwAQw">French</a> <i id="mwAQ0">Terre</i>). The Latinate form <i id="mwAQ4">GÃ¦a</i> or <i id="mwAQ8">Gaea</i> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt215" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"lang"},"2":{"wt":"&apos;"},"3":{"wt":"dÊ’"},"4":{"wt":"iË"},"5":{"wt":"."},"6":{"wt":"É™"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwARA"><small>English: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="/dÊ’/: 'j' in 'jam'">dÊ’</span><span title="/iË/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iË</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span></span>/</a></span></span>) of the Greek poetic name <i id="mwARE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gaia" title="Gaia" id="mwARI">Gaia</a></i> (<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt216" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc"},"2":{"wt":"Î“Î±á¿–Î±"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwARM"><span lang="grc">Î“Î±á¿–Î±</span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt216" id="mwARQ"/>; <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPA","href":"./Template:IPA"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc"},"2":{"wt":"É¡Ã¢iÌ¯.a"},"3":{"wt":"lang"},"link":{"wt":"yes"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwARU">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small" about="#mwt217"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language" class="mw-redirect">Ancient Greek</a>:</span><span about="#mwt217"> </span><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="grc-Latn-fonipa" about="#mwt217"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>É¡Ã¢iÌ¯.a<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_with_Ancient_Greek_IPA" title="Help:IPA/Greek"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>É¡Ã¢j.ja<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_with_Greek_IPA" about="#mwt220" id="mwARg"/>) is rare, though the alternative spelling <i id="mwARk">Gaia</i> has become common due to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gaia_hypothesis" title="Gaia hypothesis" id="mwARo">Gaia hypothesis</a>, in which case its pronunciation is <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt221" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"2":{"wt":"g"},"3":{"wt":"aÉª"},"4":{"wt":"."},"5":{"wt":"É™"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwARs"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="/É¡/: 'g' in 'guy'">É¡</span><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span></span>/</a></span></span> rather than the more classical English <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt222" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"2":{"wt":"g"},"3":{"wt":"eÉª"},"4":{"wt":"."},"5":{"wt":"É™"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwARw"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="/É¡/: 'g' in 'guy'">É¡</span><span title="/eÉª/: 'a' in 'face'">eÉª</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span></span>/</a></span></span>.<sup about="#mwt234" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-33" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-33"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-33" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;" id="mwAR0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAR4">[29]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAR8">There are a number of adjectives for the planet Earth. From <i id="mwASA">Earth</i> itself comes <i id="mwASE">earthly</i>. From the Latin <i id="mwASI">Terra</i> comes <i id="mwASM">terran</i> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt240" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"2":{"wt":"t"},"3":{"wt":"É›r"},"4":{"wt":"É™"},"5":{"wt":"n"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwASQ"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É›r/: 'err' in 'merry'">É›r</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup about="#mwt247" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-34" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-34"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-34" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 30;" id="mwASU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASY">[30]</span></a></sup> terrestrial <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt241" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"t"},"2":{"wt":"É™"},"3":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"4":{"wt":"r"},"5":{"wt":"É›"},"6":{"wt":"s"},"7":{"wt":"t"},"8":{"wt":"r"},"9":{"wt":"i"},"10":{"wt":"É™"},"11":{"wt":"l"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwASc"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/É›/: 'e' in 'dress'">É›</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup about="#mwt251" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-35" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-35"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-35" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 31;" id="mwASg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASk">[31]</span></a></sup> and (via French) <i id="mwASo">terrene</i> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt242" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"t"},"2":{"wt":"É™"},"3":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"4":{"wt":"r"},"5":{"wt":"iË"},"6":{"wt":"n"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwASs"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/iË/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup about="#mwt255" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-36" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-36"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-36" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 32;" id="mwASw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAS0">[32]</span></a></sup> and from the Latin <i id="mwAS4">Tellus</i> comes <i id="mwAS8">tellurian</i> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt243" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"t"},"2":{"wt":"É›"},"3":{"wt":"Ëˆ"},"4":{"wt":"l"},"5":{"wt":"ÊŠÉ™r"},"6":{"wt":"i"},"7":{"wt":"É™"},"8":{"wt":"n"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATA"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/É›/: 'e' in 'dress'">É›</span><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ÊŠÉ™r/: 'our' in 'tour'">ÊŠÉ™r</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/É™/: 'a' in 'about'">É™</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span><sup about="#mwt259" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-37" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-37"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-37" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 33;" id="mwATE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATI">[33]</span></a></sup> and <i id="mwATM">telluric</i>.<sup about="#mwt263" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-38" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-38"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-38" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 34;" id="mwATQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATU">[34]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="2" id="mwATY"><h2 id="Natural_history">Natural history</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt264" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"History of Earth"},"2":{"wt":"Timeline of natural history"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt264" id="mwATg">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_Earth" title="History of Earth">History of Earth</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Timeline_of_natural_history" title="Timeline of natural history">Timeline of natural history</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="3" id="mwATk"><h3 id="Formation">Formation</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt267" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Early Earth"},"2":{"wt":"Hadean"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATo"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt267" id="mwATs">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Earth" title="Early Earth">Early Earth</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadean" title="Hadean">Hadean</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwATw"><a href="./File:The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAT0"><img resource="./File:The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg/290px-The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2400" data-file-type="bitmap" height="218" width="290" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg/435px-The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg/580px-The_Mysterious_Case_of_the_Disappearing_Dust.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAT4"/></a><figcaption id="mwAT8">An artist's impression of the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mwAUA">Solar System</a>'s <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protoplanetary_disk" title="Protoplanetary disk" id="mwAUE">protoplanetary disk</a>, out of which Earth and other Solar System bodies were formed</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAUI">The oldest material found in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mwAUM">Solar System</a> is dated to <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt273" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4.5682"},"2":{"wt":"0.0002"},"3":{"wt":"0.0004"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAUQ"><span data-sort-value="7000456820000000000â™ "></span>4.5682<span style="margin-left:0.3em;"><span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:85%;text-align:right;">+0.0002<br/>âˆ’0.0004</span></span></span> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gigaannum" title="Gigaannum" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAUU">Ga</a> (billion years) ago.<sup about="#mwt275" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bouvier_wadhwa2010_39-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bouvier_wadhwa2010"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-bouvier_wadhwa2010-39" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 35;" id="mwAUY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUc">[35]</span></a></sup> By <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt274" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4.54"},"2":{"wt":"0.04"},"u":{"wt":"Ga"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAUg"><span data-sort-value="7017143271504000000â™ "></span>4.54<span style="margin-left:0.3em;margin-right:0.15em;">Â±</span>0.04<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ga</span> the primordial Earth had formed.<sup about="#mwt276" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-age_earth1_40-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"age_earth1"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-age_earth1-40" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 36;" id="mwAUk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUo">[36]</span></a></sup> The bodies in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Formation_and_evolution_of_the_Solar_System" title="Formation and evolution of the Solar System" id="mwAUs">the Solar System formed and evolved</a> with the Sun. In theory, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_nebula" title="Solar nebula" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAUw">solar nebula</a> partitions a volume out of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molecular_cloud" title="Molecular cloud" id="mwAU0">molecular cloud</a> by gravitational collapse, which begins to spin and flatten into a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Circumstellar_disk" title="Circumstellar disk" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAU4">circumstellar disk</a>, and then the planets grow out of that disk with the Sun. A nebula contains gas, ice grains, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cosmic_dust" title="Cosmic dust" id="mwAU8">dust</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primordial_nuclide" title="Primordial nuclide" id="mwAVA">primordial nuclides</a>). According to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nebular_theory" title="Nebular theory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVE">nebular theory</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetesimal" title="Planetesimal" id="mwAVI">planetesimals</a> formed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Accretion_(astrophysics)" title="Accretion (astrophysics)" id="mwAVM">accretion</a>, with the primordial Earth being estimated as likely taking anywhere from 70 to 100 million years to form.<sup about="#mwt280" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-41" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-41"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 37;" id="mwAVQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVU">[37]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAVY">Estimates of the age of the Moon range from 4.5 Ga to significantly younger.<sup about="#mwt290" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-42" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-42"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-42" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 38;" id="mwAVc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVg">[38]</span></a></sup> A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giant_impact_hypothesis" title="Giant impact hypothesis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVk">leading hypothesis</a> is that it was formed by accretion from material loosed from Earth after a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mars" title="Mars" id="mwAVo">Mars</a>-sized object with about 10% of Earth's mass, named <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theia_(planet)" title="Theia (planet)" id="mwAVs">Theia</a>, collided with Earth.<sup about="#mwt291" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-reilly20091022_43-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"reilly20091022"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-reilly20091022-43" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 39;" id="mwAVw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAV0">[39]</span></a></sup> It hit Earth with a glancing blow and some of its mass merged with Earth.<sup about="#mwt292" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-canup_asphaug2001b_44-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"canup_asphaug2001b"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-canup_asphaug2001b-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwAV4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAV8">[40]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt296" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-45" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-45"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-45" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 41;" id="mwAWA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWE">[41]</span></a></sup> Between approximately 4.1 and <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt286" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3.8"},"u":{"wt":"Ga"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAWI"><span data-sort-value="7017119918880000000â™ "></span>3.8<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ga</span>, numerous <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Impact_event" title="Impact event" id="mwAWM">asteroid impacts</a> during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Heavy_Bombardment" title="Late Heavy Bombardment" id="mwAWQ">Late Heavy Bombardment</a> caused significant changes to the greater surface environment of the Moon and, by inference, to that of Earth.<sup about="#mwt300" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-46" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-46"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-46" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 42;" id="mwAWU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWY">[42]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="4" id="mwAWc"><h3 id="After_formation">After formation</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt301" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Geological history of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAWg"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt301" id="mwAWk">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geological_history_of_Earth" title="Geological history of Earth">Geological history of Earth</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAWo"><a href="./File:NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAWs"><img resource="./File:NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg/290px-NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3840" data-file-height="2160" data-file-type="bitmap" height="163" width="290" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg/435px-NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg/580px-NASA-EarlyEarth-PaleOrangeDot-20190802.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAWw"/></a><figcaption id="mwAW0"><i id="mwAW4">Pale orange dot</i>, an artist's impression of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Earth" title="Early Earth" id="mwAW8">Early Earth</a>, featuring its tinted orange <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Methane" title="Methane" id="mwAXA">methane</a>-rich <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Prebiotic_atmosphere" title="Prebiotic atmosphere" id="mwAXE">early atmosphere</a><sup about="#mwt308" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Trainer_Pavlov_DeWitt_Jimenez_pp._18035â€“18042_47-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Trainer Pavlov DeWitt Jimenez pp. 18035â€“18042"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Trainer_Pavlov_DeWitt_Jimenez_pp._18035â€“18042-47"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Trainer_Pavlov_DeWitt_Jimenez_pp._18035â€“18042-47" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 43;" id="mwAXI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXM">[43]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAXQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth" id="mwAXU">Earth's atmosphere</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean" title="Ocean" id="mwAXY">oceans</a> were formed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Volcanism" title="Volcanism" id="mwAXc">volcanic activity</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Outgassing" title="Outgassing" id="mwAXg">outgassing</a>.<sup about="#mwt318" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-48" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-48"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-48" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 44;" id="mwAXk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXo">[44]</span></a></sup> Water vapor from these sources <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Origin_of_water_on_Earth" title="Origin of water on Earth" id="mwAXs">condensed</a> into the oceans, augmented by water and ice from asteroids, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protoplanet" title="Protoplanet" id="mwAXw">protoplanets</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Comet" title="Comet" id="mwAX0">comets</a>.<sup about="#mwt319" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-watersource_49-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"watersource"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-watersource-49" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 45;" id="mwAX4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAX8">[45]</span></a></sup> Sufficient water to fill the oceans may have been on Earth since it formed.<sup about="#mwt323" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-50" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-50"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-50" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 46;" id="mwAYA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYE">[46]</span></a></sup> In this model, atmospheric <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas" id="mwAYI">greenhouse gases</a> kept the oceans from freezing when the newly forming Sun <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Faint_young_Sun_paradox" title="Faint young Sun paradox" id="mwAYM">had only 70%</a> of its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_luminosity" title="Solar luminosity" id="mwAYQ">current luminosity</a>.<sup about="#mwt324" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-asp2002_51-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"asp2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-asp2002-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 47;" id="mwAYU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYY">[47]</span></a></sup> By <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt314" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3.5"},"u":{"wt":"Ga"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAYc"><span data-sort-value="7017110451600000000â™ "></span>3.5<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ga</span>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field" id="mwAYg">Earth's magnetic field</a> was established, which helped prevent the atmosphere from being stripped away by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_wind" title="Solar wind" id="mwAYk">solar wind</a>.<sup about="#mwt325" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-physorg20100304_52-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"physorg20100304"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-physorg20100304-52" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 48;" id="mwAYo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYs">[48]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAYw">As the molten outer layer of Earth cooled it <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phase_transition" title="Phase transition" id="mwAY0">formed</a> the first solid <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwAY4">crust</a>, which is thought to have been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mafic" title="Mafic" id="mwAY8">mafic</a> in composition. The first <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continental_crust" title="Continental crust" id="mwAZA">continental crust</a>, which was more <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Felsic" title="Felsic" id="mwAZE">felsic</a> in composition, formed by the partial melting of this mafic crust.<sup about="#mwt338" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-comp_53-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"comp"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-comp-53"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-comp-53" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwAZI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZM">[49]</span></a></sup> The presence of grains of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadean_zircon" title="Hadean zircon" id="mwAZQ">mineral zircon of Hadean age</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eoarchean" title="Eoarchean" id="mwAZU">Eoarchean</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sedimentary_rock" title="Sedimentary rock" id="mwAZY">sedimentary rocks</a> suggests that at least some felsic crust existed as early as <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt333" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4.4"},"u":{"wt":"Ga"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAZc"><span data-sort-value="7017138853440000000â™ "></span>4.4<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ga</span>, only <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt334" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"140"},"u":{"wt":"[[Megaannum|Ma]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAZg"><span data-sort-value="7002140000000000000â™ "></span>140<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megaannum" title="Megaannum" class="mw-redirect">Ma</a></span> after Earth's formation.<sup about="#mwt339" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-science310_5756_1947_54-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"science310_5756_1947"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-science310_5756_1947-54" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwAZk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZo">[50]</span></a></sup> There are two main models of how this initial small volume of continental crust evolved to reach its current abundance:<sup about="#mwt340" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-williams_santosh2004_55-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"williams_santosh2004"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-williams_santosh2004-55" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 51;" id="mwAZs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZw">[51]</span></a></sup> (1) a relatively steady growth up to the present day,<sup about="#mwt341" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-science164_1229_56-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"science164_1229"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-science164_1229-56" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 52;" id="mwAZ0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZ4">[52]</span></a></sup> which is supported by the radiometric dating of continental crust globally and (2) an initial rapid growth in the volume of continental crust during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archean" title="Archean" id="mwAZ8">Archean</a>, forming the bulk of the continental crust that now exists,<sup about="#mwt342" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ajes38_613_57-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ajes38_613"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ajes38_613-57" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 53;" id="mwAaA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAaE">[53]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt343" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-tp322_19_58-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"tp322_19"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-tp322_19-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 54;" id="mwAaI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAaM">[54]</span></a></sup> which is supported by isotopic evidence from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hafnium" title="Hafnium" id="mwAaQ">hafnium</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Zircon" title="Zircon" id="mwAaU">zircons</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neodymium" title="Neodymium" id="mwAaY">neodymium</a> in sedimentary rocks. The two models and the data that support them can be reconciled by large-scale <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crustal_recycling" title="Crustal recycling" id="mwAac">recycling of the continental crust</a>, particularly during the early stages of Earth's history.<sup about="#mwt344" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Dhuime_etal_2018_59-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Dhuime_etal_2018"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Dhuime_etal_2018-59" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;" id="mwAag"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAak">[55]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAao">New continental crust forms as a result of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics" id="mwAas">plate tectonics</a>, a process ultimately driven by the continuous loss of heat from Earth's interior. Over <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geologic_time_scale" title="Geologic time scale" id="mwAaw">the period</a> of hundreds of millions of years, tectonic forces have caused areas of continental crust to group together to form <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Supercontinent" title="Supercontinent" id="mwAa0">supercontinents</a> that have subsequently broken apart. At approximately <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt346" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"750"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAa4"><span data-sort-value="7016236682000000000â™ "></span>750<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, one of the earliest known supercontinents, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodinia" title="Rodinia" id="mwAa8">Rodinia</a>, began to break apart. The continents later recombined to form <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pannotia" title="Pannotia" id="mwAbA">Pannotia</a> at <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt347" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"600"},"2":{"wt":"â€“"},"3":{"wt":"540"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAbE"><span data-sort-value="7016189345600000000â™ "></span>600â€“540<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, then finally <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pangaea" title="Pangaea" id="mwAbI">Pangaea</a>, which also began to break apart at <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt348" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"180"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAbM"><span data-sort-value="7015568036800000000â™ "></span>180<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>.<sup about="#mwt349" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bradley_2011_60-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bradley_2011"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-bradley_2011-60" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;" id="mwAbQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbU">[56]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAbY">The most recent pattern of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_age" title="Ice age" id="mwAbc">ice ages</a> began about <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt354" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"40"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAbg"><span data-sort-value="7015126230400000000â™ "></span>40<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>,<sup about="#mwt359" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-61" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-61"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwAbk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbo">[57]</span></a></sup> and then intensified during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene" id="mwAbs">Pleistocene</a> about <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt355" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAbw"><span data-sort-value="7013946728000000000â™ "></span>3<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>.<sup about="#mwt363" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-62" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-62"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 58;" id="mwAb0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAb4">[58]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./High_latitude" title="High latitude" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAb8">High-</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_latitude" title="Middle latitude" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAcA">middle-latitude</a> regions have since undergone repeated cycles of glaciation and thaw, repeating about every 21,000, 41,000 and 100,000 years.<sup about="#mwt364" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-psc_63-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"psc"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-psc-63" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;" id="mwAcE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcI">[59]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Last_Glacial_Period" title="Last Glacial Period" id="mwAcM">Last Glacial Period</a>, colloquially called the "last ice age", covered large parts of the continents, to the middle latitudes, in ice and ended about 11,700 years ago.<sup about="#mwt368" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-64" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-64"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;" id="mwAcQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcU">[60]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="5" id="mwAcY"><h3 id="Origin_of_life_and_evolution">Origin of life and evolution</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt369" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Abiogenesis{{!}}Origin of life"},"2":{"wt":"Earliest known life forms"},"3":{"wt":"History of life"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAcc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt369" id="mwAcg">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abiogenesis" title="Abiogenesis">Origin of life</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earliest_known_life_forms" title="Earliest known life forms">Earliest known life forms</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_life" title="History of life">History of life</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAck"><a href="./File:Archean.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAco"><img resource="./File:Archean.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Archean.png/330px-Archean.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="2510" data-file-height="1124" data-file-type="bitmap" height="148" width="330" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Archean.png/495px-Archean.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Archean.png/660px-Archean.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAcs"/></a><figcaption id="mwAcw">Artist's impression of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archean" title="Archean" id="mwAc0">Archean</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geologic_time_scale#Divisions_of_geologic_time" title="Geologic time scale" id="mwAc4">eon</a> after Earth's formation, featuring round <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stromatolite" title="Stromatolite" id="mwAc8">stromatolites</a>, which are early oxygen-producing forms of life from billions of years ago. After the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Heavy_Bombardment" title="Late Heavy Bombardment" id="mwAdA">Late Heavy Bombardment</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwAdE">Earth's crust</a> had cooled, its water-rich barren <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_surface" title="Planetary surface" id="mwAdI">surface</a> is marked by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continent" title="Continent" id="mwAdM">continents</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Volcano" title="Volcano" id="mwAdQ">volcanoes</a>, with the Moon still orbiting Earth half as close than today, appearing 2.8 times larger and producing strong <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tide" title="Tide" id="mwAdU">tides</a>.<sup about="#mwt376" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lunar_and_Planetary_Institute_65-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lunar and Planetary Institute"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lunar_and_Planetary_Institute-65"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Lunar_and_Planetary_Institute-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwAdY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdc">[61]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAdg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chemical_reaction" title="Chemical reaction" id="mwAdk">Chemical reactions</a> led to the first self-replicating molecules about four billion years ago. A half billion years later, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Last_universal_common_ancestor" title="Last universal common ancestor" id="mwAdo">last common ancestor of all current life</a> arose.<sup about="#mwt393" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sa282_6_90_66-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sa282_6_90"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sa282_6_90-66" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;" id="mwAds"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdw">[62]</span></a></sup> The evolution of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis" id="mwAd0">photosynthesis</a> allowed the Sun's energy to be harvested directly by life forms. The resultant <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molecular_oxygen" title="Molecular oxygen" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAd4">molecular oxygen</a> (<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1123817410" about="#mwt387" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"chem2","href":"./Template:Chem2"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"O2"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAd8"/><span class="chemf nowrap" about="#mwt387" id="mwAeA">O<sub class="template-chem2-sub">2</sub></span>) accumulated in the atmosphere and due to interaction with ultraviolet solar radiation, formed a protective <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ozone_layer" title="Ozone layer" id="mwAeE">ozone layer</a> (<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1123817410" about="#mwt390" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"chem2","href":"./Template:Chem2"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"O3"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAeI"/><span class="chemf nowrap" about="#mwt390" id="mwAeM">O<sub class="template-chem2-sub">3</sub></span>) in the upper atmosphere.<sup about="#mwt397" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20131003_67-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20131003"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NYT-20131003-67"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-NYT-20131003-67" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwAeQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeU">[63]</span></a></sup> The incorporation of smaller cells within larger ones resulted in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Endosymbiotic_theory" title="Endosymbiotic theory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAeY">development of complex cells</a> called <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eukaryote" title="Eukaryote" id="mwAec">eukaryotes</a>.<sup about="#mwt398" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jas22_3_225_68-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jas22_3_225"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-jas22_3_225-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAeg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAek">[64]</span></a></sup> True multicellular organisms formed as cells within <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Colony_(biology)" title="Colony (biology)" id="mwAeo">colonies</a> became increasingly specialized. Aided by the absorption of harmful <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ultraviolet_radiation" title="Ultraviolet radiation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAes">ultraviolet radiation</a> by the ozone layer, life colonized Earth's surface.<sup about="#mwt399" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-burton20021129_69-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"burton20021129"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-burton20021129-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAew"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAe0">[65]</span></a></sup> Among the earliest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossil" title="Fossil" id="mwAe4">fossil</a> evidence for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Life" title="Life" id="mwAe8">life</a> is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microbial_mat" title="Microbial mat" id="mwAfA">microbial mat</a> fossils found in 3.48<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAfE">Â </span>billion-year-old <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sandstone" title="Sandstone" id="mwAfI">sandstone</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Western_Australia" title="Western Australia" id="mwAfM">Western Australia</a>,<sup about="#mwt403" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-70" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-70"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-70" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 66;" id="mwAfQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAfU">[66]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biogenic_substance" title="Biogenic substance" id="mwAfY">biogenic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Graphite" title="Graphite" id="mwAfc">graphite</a> found in 3.7<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAfg">Â </span>billion-year-old <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metasediment" title="Metasediment" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAfk">metasedimentary</a> rocks in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Western_Greenland" title="Western Greenland" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAfo">Western Greenland</a>,<sup about="#mwt407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-71" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-71"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-71" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwAfs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAfw">[67]</span></a></sup> and remains of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biotic_material" title="Biotic material" id="mwAf0">biotic material</a> found in 4.1<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAf4">Â </span>billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia.<sup about="#mwt411" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-72" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-72"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-72" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 68;" id="mwAf8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgA">[68]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt415" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-73" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-73"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-73" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAgE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgI">[69]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earliest_known_life_forms" title="Earliest known life forms" id="mwAgM">earliest direct evidence of life</a> on Earth is contained in 3.45 billion-year-old <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Australia_(continent)" title="Australia (continent)" id="mwAgQ">Australian</a> rocks showing fossils of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microorganism" title="Microorganism" id="mwAgU">microorganisms</a>.<sup about="#mwt419" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-74" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-74"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-74" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;" id="mwAgY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgc">[70]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt423" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-75" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-75"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-75" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;" id="mwAgg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgk">[71]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAgo">During the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neoproterozoic" title="Neoproterozoic" id="mwAgs">Neoproterozoic</a>, <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt429" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1000"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"539"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAgw"><span data-sort-value="7016315576000000000â™ "></span>1000 to 539<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, much of Earth might have been covered in ice. This hypothesis has been termed "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Snowball_Earth" title="Snowball Earth" id="mwAg0">Snowball Earth</a>", and it is of particular interest because it preceded the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cambrian_explosion" title="Cambrian explosion" id="mwAg4">Cambrian explosion</a>, when multicellular life forms significantly increased in complexity.<sup about="#mwt437" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-76" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-76"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-76" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 72;" id="mwAg8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhA">[72]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt441" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-77" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-77"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-77" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 73;" id="mwAhE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhI">[73]</span></a></sup> Following the Cambrian explosion, <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt430" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"535"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAhM"><span data-sort-value="7016168833160000000â™ "></span>535<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, there have been at least five major <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction_event" title="Extinction event" id="mwAhQ">mass extinctions</a> and many minor ones.<sup about="#mwt442" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Stanley_2016_78-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Stanley_2016"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Stanley_2016-78" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 74;" id="mwAhU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhY">[74]</span></a></sup> Apart from the proposed current <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction" id="mwAhc">Holocene extinction</a> event, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceousâ€“Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceousâ€“Paleogene extinction event" id="mwAhg">most recent</a> was <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt431" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"66"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAhk"><span data-sort-value="7015208280160000000â™ "></span>66<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, when <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chicxulub_impactor" title="Chicxulub impactor" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAho">an asteroid impact</a> triggered the extinction of the non-avian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur" id="mwAhs">dinosaurs</a> and other large reptiles, but largely spared small animals such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insect" title="Insect" id="mwAhw">insects</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal" title="Mammal" id="mwAh0">mammals</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lizard" title="Lizard" id="mwAh4">lizards</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird" title="Bird" id="mwAh8">birds</a>. Mammalian life has diversified over the past <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt432" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"66"},"u":{"wt":"Mys"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAiA"><span data-sort-value="7001660000000000000â™ "></span>66<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Mys</span>, and several million years ago an African <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ape" title="Ape" id="mwAiE">ape</a> species gained the ability to stand upright.<sup about="#mwt443" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-gould1994_79-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"gould1994"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-gould1994-79" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;" id="mwAiI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiM">[75]</span></a></sup><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_lacking_reliable_references" about="#mwt433" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"better source needed","href":"./Template:Better_source_needed"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"February 2023"},"reason":{"wt":"Very old source in the context of human evolution, new knowledge of how bipedalism relates to human evolution means this statement may no longer be relevant."}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAiQ"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_lacking_reliable_references_from_February_2023" about="#mwt433"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt433" id="mwAiU"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect"><span title="Very old source in the context of human evolution, new knowledge of how bipedalism relates to human evolution means this statement may no longer be relevant. (February 2023)">better<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>source<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>needed</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> This facilitated tool use and encouraged communication that provided the nutrition and stimulation needed for a larger brain, which led to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_evolution" title="Human evolution" id="mwAiY">evolution of humans</a>. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_agriculture" title="History of agriculture" id="mwAic">development of agriculture</a>, and then <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_ancient_civilizations" title="List of ancient civilizations" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAig">civilization</a>, led to humans having an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment" id="mwAik">influence on Earth</a> and the nature and quantity of other life forms that continues to this day.<sup about="#mwt444" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bgsa119_1_140_80-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bgsa119_1_140"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-bgsa119_1_140-80" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 76;" id="mwAio"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAis">[76]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="6" id="mwAiw"><h3 id="Future">Future</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt445" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Future of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAi0"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt445" id="mwAi4">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Future_of_Earth" title="Future of Earth">Future of Earth</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt455" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Global catastrophic risk"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAi8"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt455" id="mwAjA">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Global_catastrophic_risk" title="Global catastrophic risk">Global catastrophic risk</a></div><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAjE"><a href="./File:Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAjI"><img alt="A dark gray and red sphere representing the Earth lies against a black background to the right of an orange circular object representing the Sun" resource="./File:Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg/280px-Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="541" data-file-type="bitmap" height="189" width="280" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg/420px-Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg/560px-Red_Giant_Earth_warm.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAjM"/></a><figcaption id="mwAjQ">Conjectured illustration of the scorched Earth after the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sun" title="Sun" id="mwAjU">Sun</a> has entered the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_giant" title="Red giant" id="mwAjY">red giant</a> phase, about 5â€“7 billion years from now</figcaption></figure><p id="mwAjc">Earth's expected long-term future is tied to that of the Sun. Over the next <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt458" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.1"},"u":{"wt":"billion years"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAjg"><span data-sort-value="7000110000000000000â™ "></span>1.1<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>billion years</span>, solar luminosity will increase by 10%, and over the next <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt459" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3.5"},"u":{"wt":"billion years"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAjk"><span data-sort-value="7000350000000000000â™ "></span>3.5<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>billion years</span> by 40%.<sup about="#mwt466" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sun_future_81-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sun_future"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sun_future-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAjo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjs">[77]</span></a></sup> Earth's increasing surface temperature will accelerate the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carbonateâ€“silicate_cycle" title="Carbonateâ€“silicate cycle" id="mwAjw">inorganic carbon cycle</a>, reducing <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1123817410" about="#mwt460" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"chem2","href":"./Template:Chem2"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"CO2"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAj0"/><span class="chemf nowrap" about="#mwt460" id="mwAj4">CO<sub class="template-chem2-sub">2</sub></span> concentration to levels lethally low for plants (<span class="nowrap" about="#mwt463" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"10"},"ul":{"wt":"ppm"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAj8"><span data-sort-value="6995099999999999999â™ "></span>10<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parts_per_million" title="Parts per million" class="mw-redirect">ppm</a></span> for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./C4_carbon_fixation" title="C4 carbon fixation" id="mwAkA">C4 photosynthesis</a>) in approximately <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt464" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"2":{"wt":"â€“"},"3":{"wt":"900"},"u":{"wt":"million years"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAkE"><span data-sort-value="7002100000000000000â™ "></span>100â€“900<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>million years</span>.<sup about="#mwt467" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-britt2000_82-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"britt2000"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-britt2000-82" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwAkI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkM">[78]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt468" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pnas1_24_9576_83-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pnas1_24_9576"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-pnas1_24_9576-83" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 79;" id="mwAkQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkU">[79]</span></a></sup> The lack of vegetation will result in the loss of oxygen in the atmosphere, making animal life impossible.<sup about="#mwt469" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ward_brownlee2002_84-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ward_brownlee2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ward_brownlee2002-84" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 80;" id="mwAkY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkc">[80]</span></a></sup> Due to the increased luminosity, Earth's mean temperature may reach <span about="#mwt465" typeof="mw:Transclusion"
