data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"},"4":{"wt":"0"},"abbr":{"wt":""}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAkg">100</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt465">Â </span><span about="#mwt465">Â°C (212</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt465">Â </span><span about="#mwt465">Â°F)</span> in 1.5 billion years, and all ocean water will evaporate and be lost to space, which may trigger a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Runaway_greenhouse_effect" title="Runaway greenhouse effect" id="mwAkk">runaway greenhouse effect</a>, within an estimated 1.6 to 3 billion years.<sup about="#mwt473" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mello-2020_85-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mello-2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Mello-2020-85"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Mello-2020-85" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;" id="mwAko"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAks">[81]</span></a></sup> Even if the Sun were stable, a fraction of the water in the modern oceans will descend to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)" id="mwAkw">mantle</a>, due to reduced steam venting from mid-ocean ridges.<sup about="#mwt474" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mello-2020_85-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mello-2020"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Mello-2020-85" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;" id="mwAk0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAk4">[81]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt475" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hess5_4_569_86-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hess5_4_569"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-hess5_4_569-86" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 82;" id="mwAk8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlA">[82]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAlE">The Sun will <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stellar_evolution" title="Stellar evolution" id="mwAlI">evolve</a> to become a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_giant" title="Red giant" id="mwAlM">red giant</a> in about <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt479" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"5"},"u":{"wt":"billion years"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAlQ"><span data-sort-value="7000500000000000000â™ "></span>5<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>billion years</span>. Models predict that the Sun will expand to roughly <span about="#mwt480" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1"},"2":{"wt":"AU"},"3":{"wt":"e6km e6mi"},"lk":{"wt":"in"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAlU">1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt480">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Astronomical_unit" title="Astronomical unit" about="#mwt480">AU</a><span about="#mwt480"> (150</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt480">Â </span><span about="#mwt480">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt480">Â </span><span about="#mwt480">km; 93</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt480">Â </span><span about="#mwt480">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt480">Â </span><span about="#mwt480">mi)</span>, about 250 times its present radius.<sup about="#mwt482" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sun_future_81-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sun_future"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sun_future-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAlY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlc">[77]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt483" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sun_future_schroder_87-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sun_future_schroder"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sun_future_schroder-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 83;" id="mwAlg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlk">[83]</span></a></sup> Earth's fate is less clear. As a red giant, the Sun will lose roughly 30% of its mass, so, without tidal effects, Earth will move to an orbit <span about="#mwt481" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.7"},"2":{"wt":"AU"},"3":{"wt":"e6km e6mi"},"lk":{"wt":"off"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAlo">1.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt481">Â </span><span about="#mwt481">AU (250</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt481">Â </span><span about="#mwt481">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt481">Â </span><span about="#mwt481">km; 160</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt481">Â </span><span about="#mwt481">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt481">Â </span><span about="#mwt481">mi)</span> from the Sun when the star reaches its maximum radius, otherwise, with tidal effects, it may enter the Sun's atmosphere and be vaporized.<sup about="#mwt484" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sun_future_81-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sun_future"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sun_future-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAls"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlw">[77]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="7" id="mwAl0"><h2 id="Geophysical_characteristics">Geophysical characteristics</h2>
<!--linked from 'Earth physical characteristics tables'-->
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt485" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Geophysics"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAl4"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt485" id="mwAl8">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geophysics" title="Geophysics">Geophysics</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="8" id="mwAmA"><h3 id="Size_and_shape">Size and shape</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt488" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Figure of the Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAmE"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt488" id="mwAmI">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Figure_of_the_Earth" title="Figure of the Earth">Figure of the Earth</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt491" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth radius"},"2":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s circumference"},"3":{"wt":"Spherical Earth{{!}}Earth curvature"},"4":{"wt":"Geomorphology"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAmM"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt491" id="mwAmQ">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_radius" title="Earth radius">Earth radius</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_circumference" title="Earth's circumference">Earth's circumference</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spherical_Earth" title="Spherical Earth">Earth curvature</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geomorphology" title="Geomorphology">Geomorphology</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt494" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"List of highest mountains on Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAmU"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt494" id="mwAmY">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_highest_mountains_on_Earth" title="List of highest mountains on Earth">List of highest mountains on Earth</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAmc"><a href="./File:Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAmg"><img resource="./File:Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/260px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1362" data-file-type="bitmap" height="236" width="260" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/390px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/520px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAmk"/></a><figcaption id="mwAmo">Earth's western hemisphere showing topography relative to Earth's center (instead of to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mean_sea_level" title="Mean sea level" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAms">mean sea level</a>, as in common topographic maps)</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAmw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Figure_of_the_Earth" title="Figure of the Earth" id="mwAm0">Earth has a rounded shape</a>, through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrostatic_equilibrium" title="Hydrostatic equilibrium" id="mwAm4">hydrostatic equilibrium</a>,<sup about="#mwt502" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Horner_2021_88-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Horner 2021"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Horner_2021-88"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Horner_2021-88" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;" id="mwAm8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnA">[84]</span></a></sup> with an average diameter of <span about="#mwt498" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"12742"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAnE">12,742 kilometers (7,918</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt498">Â </span><span about="#mwt498">mi)</span>, making it the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_Solar_System_objects_by_size" title="List of Solar System objects by size" id="mwAnI">fifth largest</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planet#Planetary-mass_object" title="Planet" id="mwAnM">planetary sized</a> and largest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet" id="mwAnQ">terrestrial object</a> of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mwAnU">Solar System</a>.</p>

<p id="mwAnY">Due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_rotation" title="Earth's rotation" id="mwAnc">Earth's rotation</a> it has the shape of an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_ellipsoid" title="Earth ellipsoid" id="mwAng">ellipsoid</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Equatorial_bulge" title="Equatorial bulge" id="mwAnk">bulging at its Equator</a>; its diameter is <span about="#mwt505" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"43"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAno">43 kilometers (27</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt505">Â </span><span about="#mwt505">mi)</span> longer there than at its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geographical_pole" title="Geographical pole" id="mwAns">poles</a>.<sup about="#mwt506" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ngdc2006_89-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ngdc2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ngdc2006-89" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;" id="mwAnw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAn0">[85]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt507" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-milbert_smith96_90-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"milbert_smith96"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-milbert_smith96-90" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 86;" id="mwAn4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAn8">[86]</span></a></sup>
Earth's shape furthermore has local <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Topography" title="Topography" id="mwAoA">topographic</a> variations. Though the largest local variations, like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mariana_Trench" title="Mariana Trench" id="mwAoE">Mariana Trench</a> (<span about="#mwt513" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"10925"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"disp":{"wt":"or"},"abbr":{"wt":""},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAoI">10,925 meters or 35,843 feet</span> below local sea level),<sup about="#mwt527" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-91" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-91"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-91" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwAoM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoQ">[87]</span></a></sup> only shortens Earth's average radius by 0.17% and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest" id="mwAoU">Mount Everest</a> (<span about="#mwt514" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"8848"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"disp":{"wt":"or"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAoY">8,848 meters or 29,029 feet</span> above local sea level) lengthens it by only 0.14%.<sup about="#mwt515" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-93" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Transclusion mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"refn","href":"./Template:Refn"},"params":{"group":{"wt":"n"},"1":{"wt":" If Earth were shrunk to the size of a [[billiard ball]], some areas of Earth such as large mountain ranges and oceanic trenches would feel like tiny imperfections, whereas much of the planet, including the [[Great Plains]] and the [[abyssal plain]]s, would feel smoother.&lt;ref>{{cite web |url=http://billiards.colostate.edu/bd_articles/2013/june13.pdf |title=Is a Pool Ball Smoother than the Earth? |publisher=Billiards Digest |date=1 June 2013 |access-date=26 November 2014}}&lt;/ref>"}},"i":0}}]}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 5;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwAoc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAog">[n 5]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt531" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-94" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-94"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-94" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 89;" id="mwAok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoo">[89]</span></a></sup> Since Earth's surface is farthest out from Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Center_of_mass" title="Center of mass" id="mwAos">center of mass</a> at its equatorial bulge, the summit of the volcano <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chimborazo" title="Chimborazo" id="mwAow">Chimborazo</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecuador" title="Ecuador" id="mwAo0">Ecuador</a> (<span about="#mwt523" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"6384.4"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"4":{"wt":"1"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"},"disp":{"wt":"or"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAo4">6,384.4</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt523">Â </span><span about="#mwt523">km or 3,967.1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt523">Â </span><span about="#mwt523">mi</span>) is its farthest point out.<sup about="#mwt532" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ps20_5_16_95-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ps20_5_16"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ps20_5_16-95" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 90;" id="mwAo8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApA">[90]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt536" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-96" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-96"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-96" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwApE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApI">[91]</span></a></sup>
Parallel to the rigid land topography <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_surface_topography" title="Ocean surface topography" id="mwApM">the Ocean exhibits a more dynamic topography</a>.<sup about="#mwt541" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-97" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-97"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-97" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;" id="mwApQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApU">[92]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwApY">To measure the local variation of Earth's topography, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geodesy" title="Geodesy" id="mwApc">geodesy</a> employs an idealized Earth producing a shape called a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geoid" title="Geoid" id="mwApg">geoid</a>. Such a geoid shape is gained if the ocean is idealized, covering Earth completely and without any perturbations such as tides and winds. The result is a smooth but gravitational irregular geoid surface, providing a mean <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_level" title="Sea level" id="mwApk">sea level</a> (MSL) as a reference level for topographic measurements.<sup about="#mwt546" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-98" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-98"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 93;" id="mwApo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAps">[93]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="9" id="mwApw"><h3 id="Surface">Surface</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt547" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Planetary surface"},"2":{"wt":"Land cover"},"3":{"wt":"Land"},"4":{"wt":"Pedosphere"},"5":{"wt":"Ocean"},"6":{"wt":"Sea"},"7":{"wt":"Cryosphere"},"8":{"wt":"Peplosphere"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAp0"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt547" id="mwAp4">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_surface" title="Planetary surface">Planetary surface</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land_cover" title="Land cover">Land cover</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land" title="Land">Land</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pedosphere" title="Pedosphere">Pedosphere</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean" title="Ocean">Ocean</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea" title="Sea">Sea</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cryosphere" title="Cryosphere">Cryosphere</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Peplosphere" title="Peplosphere" class="mw-redirect">Peplosphere</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAp8"><a href="./File:Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAqA"><img resource="./File:Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg/220px-Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="8400" data-file-height="8400" data-file-type="bitmap" height="220" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg/330px-Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg/440px-Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAqE"/></a><figcaption id="mwAqI">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Compositing" title="Compositing" id="mwAqM">composite</a> image of Earth, with its different types of surface discernible: Earth's surface dominating <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean" title="Ocean" id="mwAqQ">Ocean</a> (blue), Africa with lush (green) to dry (brown) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land" title="Land" id="mwAqU">land</a> and Earth's polar ice in the form of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_sea_ice" title="Antarctic sea ice" id="mwAqY">Antarctic sea ice</a> (grey) covering the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_Ocean" title="Southern Ocean" id="mwAqc">Antarctic or Southern Ocean</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_ice_sheet" title="Antarctic ice sheet" id="mwAqg">Antarctic ice sheet</a> (white) covering <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwAqk">Antarctica</a>.</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAqo">Earth's surface is the boundary between the atmosphere, and the solid Earth and oceans. Defined in this way, Earth's shape is an idealized <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spheroid" title="Spheroid" id="mwAqs">spheroid</a> â€“ a squashed sphere â€“ with a surface area of about <span about="#mwt551" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"510"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"4":{"wt":"0"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAqw">510</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt551">Â </span><span about="#mwt551">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt551">Â </span><span about="#mwt551">km</span><sup about="#mwt551">2</sup><span about="#mwt551"> (197</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt551">Â </span><span about="#mwt551">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt551">Â </span><span about="#mwt551">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt551">Â </span><span about="#mwt551">mi)</span>.<sup about="#mwt552" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_15-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Pidwirny 2006_8"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Pidwirny_2006_8-15" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 12;" id="mwAq0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAq4">[12]</span></a></sup> Earth can be divided into two <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hemispheres_of_Earth" title="Hemispheres of Earth" id="mwAq8">hemispheres</a>: by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latitude" title="Latitude" id="mwArA">latitude</a> into the polar <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere" id="mwArE">Northern</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere" id="mwArI">Southern</a> hemispheres; or by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Longitude" title="Longitude" id="mwArM">longitude</a> into the continental <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eastern_Hemisphere" title="Eastern Hemisphere" id="mwArQ">Eastern</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere" id="mwArU">Western</a> hemispheres.</p>

<p id="mwArY">Most of Earth's surface is ocean water: 70.8% or <span about="#mwt562" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"361"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwArc">361</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt562">Â </span><span about="#mwt562">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt562">Â </span><span about="#mwt562">km</span><sup about="#mwt562">2</sup><span about="#mwt562"> (139</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt562">Â </span><span about="#mwt562">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt562">Â </span><span about="#mwt562">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt562">Â </span><span about="#mwt562">mi)</span>.<sup about="#mwt566" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Percentage_99-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Percentage"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Percentage-99"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Percentage-99" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 94;" id="mwArg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArk">[94]</span></a></sup> This vast pool of salty water is often called the <i id="mwAro">world ocean</i>,<sup about="#mwt570" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Janin_Mandia_2012_p._20_100-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Janin Mandia 2012 p. 20"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Janin_Mandia_2012_p._20-100"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Janin_Mandia_2012_p._20-100" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 95;" id="mwArs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArw">[95]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt574" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Ro_2020_101-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Ro 2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Ro_2020-101"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Ro_2020-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 96;" id="mwAr0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAr4">[96]</span></a></sup> and makes Earth with its dynamic <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrosphere" title="Hydrosphere" id="mwAr8">hydrosphere</a> a water world<sup about="#mwt578" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Smith_2021_102-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Smith 2021"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Smith_2021-102"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Smith_2021-102" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 97;" id="mwAsA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsE">[97]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt582" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-National_Geographic_Society_2022_103-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"National Geographic Society 2022"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-National_Geographic_Society_2022-103"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-National_Geographic_Society_2022-103" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwAsI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsM">[98]</span></a></sup> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_world" title="Ocean world" id="mwAsQ">ocean world</a>.<sup about="#mwt586" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lunine_2017_pp._123â€“130_104-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lunine 2017 pp. 123â€“130"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lunine_2017_pp._123â€“130-104"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Lunine_2017_pp._123â€“130-104" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 99;" id="mwAsU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsY">[99]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt590" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Ocean_Worlds_105-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Ocean Worlds"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Ocean_Worlds-105"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Ocean_Worlds-105" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 100;" id="mwAsc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsg">[100]</span></a></sup> Indeed, in Earth's early history the ocean may have covered Earth completely.<sup about="#mwt594" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Voosen_p._106-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Voosen p."},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Voosen_p.-106"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Voosen_p.-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwAsk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAso">[101]</span></a></sup> The world ocean is commonly divided into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean" id="mwAss">Pacific Ocean</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean" id="mwAsw">Atlantic Ocean</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean" id="mwAs0">Indian Ocean</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_Ocean" title="Southern Ocean" id="mwAs4">Antarctic or Southern Ocean</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arctic_Ocean" title="Arctic Ocean" id="mwAs8">Arctic Ocean</a>, from largest to smallest. The ocean covers <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust" id="mwAtA">Earth's oceanic crust</a>, but to a lesser extent with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shelf_sea" title="Shelf sea" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAtE">shelf seas</a> also <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf" id="mwAtI">shelves</a> of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continental_crust" title="Continental crust" id="mwAtM">continental crust</a>. The oceanic crust forms large <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_basin" title="Oceanic basin" id="mwAtQ">oceanic basins</a> with features like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abyssal_plain" title="Abyssal plain" id="mwAtU">abyssal plains</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Seamount" title="Seamount" id="mwAtY">seamounts</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Submarine_volcano" title="Submarine volcano" id="mwAtc">submarine volcanoes</a>,<sup about="#mwt595" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ngdc2006_89-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ngdc2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ngdc2006-89" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;" id="mwAtg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtk">[85]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_trench" title="Oceanic trench" id="mwAto">oceanic trenches</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Submarine_canyon" title="Submarine canyon" id="mwAts">submarine canyons</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_plateau" title="Oceanic plateau" id="mwAtw">oceanic plateaus</a>, and a globe-spanning <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mid-ocean_ridge" title="Mid-ocean ridge" id="mwAt0">mid-ocean ridge</a> system.</p>

<p id="mwAt4">At Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_regions_of_Earth" title="Polar regions of Earth" id="mwAt8">polar regions</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_surface" title="Ocean surface" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAuA">ocean surface</a> is covered by seasonally variable amounts of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_ice" title="Sea ice" id="mwAuE">sea ice</a> that often connects with polar land, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permafrost" title="Permafrost" id="mwAuI">permafrost</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet" id="mwAuM">ice sheets</a>, forming <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_ice_cap" title="Polar ice cap" id="mwAuQ">polar ice caps</a>.</p>

<p id="mwAuU">Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land" title="Land" id="mwAuY">land</a> covers 29.2%, or <span about="#mwt600" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"149"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAuc">149</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt600">Â </span><span about="#mwt600">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt600">Â </span><span about="#mwt600">km</span><sup about="#mwt600">2</sup><span about="#mwt600"> (58</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt600">Â </span><span about="#mwt600">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt600">Â </span><span about="#mwt600">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt600">Â </span><span about="#mwt600">mi)</span> of Earth's surface. The land surface includes many <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Island" title="Island" id="mwAug">islands</a> around the globe, but most of the land surface is taken by the four continental <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Landmass" title="Landmass" id="mwAuk">landmasses</a>, which are (in descending order): <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Afro-Eurasia" title="Afro-Eurasia" id="mwAuo">Africa-Eurasia</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Americas" title="Americas" id="mwAus">America (landmass)</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwAuw">Antarctica</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mainland_Australia" title="Mainland Australia" id="mwAu0">Australia (landmass)</a>.<sup about="#mwt607" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DunnMitchell2016_107-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DunnMitchell2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-DunnMitchell2016-107"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-DunnMitchell2016-107" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 102;" id="mwAu4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAu8">[102]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt611" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Dempsey_2013_108-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Dempsey 2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Dempsey_2013-108"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Dempsey_2013-108" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 103;" id="mwAvA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvE">[103]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt615" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-McColl_109-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"McColl"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-McColl-109"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-McColl-109" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;" id="mwAvI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvM">[104]</span></a></sup> These landmasses are further broken down and grouped into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continent" title="Continent" id="mwAvQ">continents</a>. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrain" title="Terrain" id="mwAvU">terrain</a> of the land surface varies greatly and consists of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mountain" title="Mountain" id="mwAvY">mountains</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Desert" title="Desert" id="mwAvc">deserts</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plain" title="Plain" id="mwAvg">plains</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plateau" title="Plateau" id="mwAvk">plateaus</a>, and other <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Landform" title="Landform" id="mwAvo">landforms</a>. The elevation of the land surface varies from a low point of <span about="#mwt601" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"-418"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAvs">âˆ’418</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt601">Â </span><span about="#mwt601">m (âˆ’1,371</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt601">Â </span><span about="#mwt601">ft)</span> at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea" id="mwAvw">Dead Sea</a>, to a maximum altitude of <span about="#mwt602" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"8,848"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAv0">8,848</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt602">Â </span><span about="#mwt602">m (29,029</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt602">Â </span><span about="#mwt602">ft)</span> at the top of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest" id="mwAv4">Mount Everest</a>. The mean height of land above sea level is about <span about="#mwt603" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"797"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAv8">797</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt603">Â </span><span about="#mwt603">m (2,615</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt603">Â </span><span about="#mwt603">ft)</span>.<sup about="#mwt619" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-110" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-110"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-110" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwAwA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwE">[105]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAwI">Land can be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land_cover" title="Land cover" id="mwAwM">covered</a> by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Surface_water" title="Surface water" id="mwAwQ">surface water</a>, snow, ice, artificial structures or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vegetation" title="Vegetation" id="mwAwU">vegetation</a>. Most of Earth's land hosts vegetation,<sup about="#mwt627" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Carlowicz_Simmon_2019_111-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Carlowicz Simmon 2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Carlowicz_Simmon_2019-111"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Carlowicz_Simmon_2019-111" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwAwY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwc">[106]</span></a></sup> but <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet" id="mwAwg">ice sheets</a> (10%,<sup about="#mwt631" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-National_Geographic_Society_2006_112-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"National Geographic Society 2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-National_Geographic_Society_2006-112"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-National_Geographic_Society_2006-112" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;" id="mwAwk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwo">[107]</span></a></sup> not including the equally large land under <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permafrost" title="Permafrost" id="mwAws">permafrost</a>)<sup about="#mwt635" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Obu_2021_p._113-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Obu 2021 p."},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Obu_2021_p.-113"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Obu_2021_p.-113" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 108;" id="mwAww"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAw0">[108]</span></a></sup> or cold as well as hot <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Desert" title="Desert" id="mwAw4">deserts</a> (33%)<sup about="#mwt639" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Cain_2010_114-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Cain 2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Cain_2010-114"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Cain_2010-114" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwAw8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxA">[109]</span></a></sup> occupy also considerable amounts of it.</p>

<p id="mwAxE">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pedosphere" title="Pedosphere" id="mwAxI">pedosphere</a> is the outermost layer of Earth's land surface and is composed of soil and subject to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soil_formation" title="Soil formation" id="mwAxM">soil formation</a> processes. Soil is crucial for land to be arable. Earth's total <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arable_land" title="Arable land" id="mwAxQ">arable land</a> is 10.7% of the land surface, with 1.3% being permanent cropland.<sup about="#mwt648" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-115" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-115"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 110;" id="mwAxU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxY">[110]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt652" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-116" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-116"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-116" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 111;" id="mwAxc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxg">[111]</span></a></sup> Earth has an estimated <span about="#mwt643" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"16.7"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAxk">16.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt643">Â </span><span about="#mwt643">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt643">Â </span><span about="#mwt643">km</span><sup about="#mwt643">2</sup><span about="#mwt643"> (6.4</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt643">Â </span><span about="#mwt643">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt643">Â </span><span about="#mwt643">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt643">Â </span><span about="#mwt643">mi)</span> of cropland and <span about="#mwt644" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"33.5"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAxo">33.5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt644">Â </span><span about="#mwt644">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt644">Â </span><span about="#mwt644">km</span><sup about="#mwt644">2</sup><span about="#mwt644"> (12.9</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt644">Â </span><span about="#mwt644">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt644">Â </span><span about="#mwt644">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt644">Â </span><span about="#mwt644">mi)</span> of pastureland.<sup about="#mwt656" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Hooke2012_117-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Hooke2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Hooke2012-117"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Hooke2012-117" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 112;" id="mwAxs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxw">[112]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAx0">The land surface and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_floor" title="Ocean floor" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAx4">ocean floor</a> form the top of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwAx8">Earth's crust</a>, which together with parts of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_mantle_(Earth)" title="Upper mantle (Earth)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAyA">upper mantle</a> form <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lithosphere#Earth's_lithosphere" title="Lithosphere" id="mwAyE">Earth's lithosphere</a>. Earth's crust may be divided into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust" id="mwAyI">oceanic</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continental_crust" title="Continental crust" id="mwAyM">continental</a> crust. Beneath the ocean-floor sediments, the oceanic crust is predominantly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Basalt" title="Basalt" id="mwAyQ">basaltic</a>, while the continental crust may include lower density materials such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Granite" title="Granite" id="mwAyU">granite</a>, sediments and metamorphic rocks.<sup about="#mwt659" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-layers_earth_118-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"layers_earth"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-layers_earth-118" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 113;" id="mwAyY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyc">[113]</span></a></sup> Nearly 75% of the continental surfaces are covered by sedimentary rocks, although they form about 5% of the mass of the crust.<sup about="#mwt660" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jessey_119-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jessey"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-jessey-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 114;" id="mwAyg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyk">[114]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAyo"><a href="./File:AYool_topography_15min.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAys"><img resource="./File:AYool_topography_15min.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/280px-AYool_topography_15min.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1617" data-file-height="1133" data-file-type="bitmap" height="196" width="280" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/420px-AYool_topography_15min.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/560px-AYool_topography_15min.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwAyw"/></a><figcaption id="mwAy0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrain" title="Terrain" id="mwAy4">Relief</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwAy8">Earth's crust</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAzA">Earth's surface <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Topography" title="Topography" id="mwAzE">topography</a> comprises both the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_surface_topography" title="Ocean surface topography" id="mwAzI">topography of the ocean surface</a>, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypsometry" title="Hypsometry" id="mwAzM">shape</a> of Earth's land surface. The submarine terrain of the ocean floor has an average <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bathymetric" title="Bathymetric" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAzQ">bathymetric</a> depth of 4<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAzU">Â </span>km, and is as varied as the terrain above sea level.</p>

<p id="mwAzY">Earth's surface is continually being shaped by internal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plate_tectonic" title="Plate tectonic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAzc">plate tectonic</a> processes including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earthquakes" title="Earthquakes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAzg">earthquakes</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Volcanism" title="Volcanism" id="mwAzk">volcanism</a>; by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weathering" title="Weathering" id="mwAzo">weathering</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erosion" title="Erosion" id="mwAzs">erosion</a> driven by ice, water, wind and temperature; and by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biological_processes" title="Biological processes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAzw">biological processes</a> including the growth and decomposition of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biomass" title="Biomass" id="mwAz0">biomass</a> into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soil" title="Soil" id="mwAz4">soil</a>.<sup about="#mwt663" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kring_120-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kring"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-kring-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwAz8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0A">[115]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt667" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-121" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-121"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-121" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 116;" id="mwA0E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0I">[116]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="10" id="mwA0M"><h3 id="Tectonic_plates">Tectonic plates</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt668" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Plate tectonics"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA0Q"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt668" id="mwA0U">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">Plate tectonics</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA0Y"><a href="./File:Tectonic_plates_(empty).svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA0c"><img alt="Shows the extent and boundaries of rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_tectonic_plates" title="List of tectonic plates" id="mwA0o">Earth's major plates</a>, which are:<sup about="#mwt692" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brown_wohletz2005_122-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brown_wohletz2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-brown_wohletz2005-122" ol>li:first-child::before,.mw-parser-output .hlist dt ol>li:first-child::before,.mw-parser-output .hlist li ol>li:first-child::before{content:" ("counter(listitem)"\a0 "}</style><div class="hlist" about="#mwt673" id="mwA04"><ul><li><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" about="#mwt684" class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fb9a7a; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./African_Plate" title="African Plate">African Plate</a><sup about="#mwt686" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jaes41_3_379_123-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"group":"n","name":"jaes41_3_379"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-jaes41_3_379-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 6;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwA08"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1A">[n 6]</span></a></sup></span></li><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt687" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Legend/styles.css"}}'/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ac8d7f; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plate</a></span></li><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt688" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Legend/styles.css"}}'/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#7fa172; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian Plate</a></span></li><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt689" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Legend/styles.css"}}'/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#8a9dbe; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate">Antarctic Plate</a></span></li><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt690" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Legend/styles.css"}}'/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fcb482; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a></span></li><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt691" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Legend/styles.css"}}'/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ad82b0; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a></span></li></ul></div></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwA1E">Earth's mechanically rigid outer layer of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwA1I">Earth's crust</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_mantle_(Earth)" title="Upper mantle (Earth)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA1M">upper mantle</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lithosphere" title="Lithosphere" id="mwA1Q">lithosphere</a>, is divided into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_tectonic_plates" title="List of tectonic plates" id="mwA1U">tectonic plates</a>. These plates are rigid segments that move relative to each other at one of three boundaries types: at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Convergent_boundary" title="Convergent boundary" id="mwA1Y">convergent boundaries</a>, two plates come together; at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Divergent_boundary" title="Divergent boundary" id="mwA1c">divergent boundaries</a>, two plates are pulled apart; and at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Transform_fault" title="Transform fault" id="mwA1g">transform boundaries</a>, two plates slide past one another laterally. Along these plate boundaries, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earthquake" title="Earthquake" id="mwA1k">earthquakes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Volcanism" title="Volcanism" id="mwA1o">volcanic activity</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Orogeny" title="Orogeny" id="mwA1s">mountain-building</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_trench" title="Oceanic trench" id="mwA1w">oceanic trench</a> formation can occur.<sup about="#mwt695" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kious_tilling1999_124-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kious_tilling1999"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-kious_tilling1999-124" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwA10"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA14">[118]</span></a></sup> The tectonic plates ride on top of the asthenosphere, the solid but less-viscous part of the upper mantle that can flow and move along with the plates.<sup about="#mwt696" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-seligman2008_125-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"seligman2008"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-seligman2008-125" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwA18"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2A">[119]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA2E">As the tectonic plates migrate, oceanic crust is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Subduction" title="Subduction" id="mwA2I">subducted</a> under the leading edges of the plates at convergent boundaries. At the same time, the upwelling of mantle material at divergent boundaries creates mid-ocean ridges. The combination of these processes recycles the oceanic crust back into the mantle. Due to this recycling, most of the ocean floor is less than <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt701" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"u":{"wt":"Myr"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA2M"><span data-sort-value="7015315576000000000â™ "></span>100<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span> old. The oldest oceanic crust is located in the Western Pacific and is estimated to be <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt702" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"200"},"u":{"wt":"Myr"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA2Q"><span data-sort-value="7015631152000000000â™ "></span>200<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span> old.<sup about="#mwt705" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-duennebier1999_126-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"duennebier1999"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-duennebier1999-126" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 120;" id="mwA2U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2Y">[120]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt706" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-noaa20070307_127-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"noaa20070307"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-noaa20070307-127" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 121;" id="mwA2c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2g">[121]</span></a></sup> By comparison, the oldest dated continental crust is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt703" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4030"},"u":{"wt":"Myr"},"fmt":{"wt":"commas"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA2k"><span data-sort-value="7017127177128000000â™ "></span>4,030<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>,<sup about="#mwt707" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cmp134_3_128-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cmp134_3"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-cmp134_3-128" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 122;" id="mwA2o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2s">[122]</span></a></sup> although zircons have been found preserved as clasts within Eoarchean sedimentary rocks that give ages up to <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt704" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4400"},"u":{"wt":"Myr"},"fmt":{"wt":"commas"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA2w"><span data-sort-value="7017138853440000000â™ "></span>4,400<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>, indicating that at least some continental crust existed at that time.<sup about="#mwt708" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-science310_5756_1947_54-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"science310_5756_1947"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-science310_5756_1947-54" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwA20"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA24">[50]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA28">The seven major plates are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate" id="mwA3A">Pacific</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate" id="mwA3E">North American</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate" id="mwA3I">Eurasian</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./African_Plate" title="African Plate" id="mwA3M">African</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate" id="mwA3Q">Antarctic</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate" id="mwA3U">Indo-Australian</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate" id="mwA3Y">South American</a>. Other notable plates include the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arabian_Plate" title="Arabian Plate" id="mwA3c">Arabian Plate</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caribbean_Plate" title="Caribbean Plate" id="mwA3g">Caribbean Plate</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nazca_Plate" title="Nazca Plate" id="mwA3k">Nazca Plate</a> off the west coast of South America and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scotia_Plate" title="Scotia Plate" id="mwA3o">Scotia Plate</a> in the southern Atlantic Ocean. The Australian Plate fused with the Indian Plate between <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt711" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"50"},"2":{"wt":"and"},"3":{"wt":"55"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA3s"><span data-sort-value="7015157788000000000â™ "></span>50 and 55<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>. The fastest-moving plates are the oceanic plates, with the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cocos_Plate" title="Cocos Plate" id="mwA3w">Cocos Plate</a> advancing at a rate of <span about="#mwt712" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"75"},"2":{"wt":"mm/year"},"3":{"wt":"in/year"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA30">75</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt712">Â </span><span about="#mwt712">mm/a (3.0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt712">Â </span><span about="#mwt712">in/year)</span><sup about="#mwt715" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-podp2000_129-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"podp2000"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-podp2000-129" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwA34"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA38">[123]</span></a></sup> and the Pacific Plate moving <span about="#mwt713" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"52"},"2":{"wt":"â€“"},"3":{"wt":"69"},"4":{"wt":"mm/year"},"5":{"wt":"in/year"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA4A">52â€“69</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt713">Â </span><span about="#mwt713">mm/a (2.0â€“2.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt713">Â </span><span about="#mwt713">in/year)</span>. At the other extreme, the slowest-moving plate is the South American Plate, progressing at a typical rate of <span about="#mwt714" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"10.6"},"2":{"wt":"mm/year"},"3":{"wt":"in/year"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA4E">10.6</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt714">Â </span><span about="#mwt714">mm/a (0.42</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt714">Â </span><span about="#mwt714">in/year)</span>.<sup about="#mwt719" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Argus_etal_2011_130-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Argus_etal_2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Argus_etal_2011-130"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Argus_etal_2011-130" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 124;" id="mwA4I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA4M">[124]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="11" id="mwA4Q"><h3 id="Internal_structure">Internal structure</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt720" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Internal structure of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA4U"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt720" id="mwA4Y">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Internal_structure_of_Earth" title="Internal structure of Earth">Internal structure of Earth</a></div>

<td id="mwA8Q">12.8â€“13.1</td></tr>

<p id="mwA8U">Earth's interior, like that of the other terrestrial planets, is divided into layers by their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chemical" title="Chemical" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8Y">chemical</a> or physical (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rheology" title="Rheology" id="mwA8c">rheological</a>) properties. The outer layer is a chemically distinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silicate_minerals" title="Silicate minerals" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8g">silicate</a> solid crust, which is underlain by a highly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Viscous" title="Viscous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8k">viscous</a> solid mantle. The crust is separated from the mantle by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./MohoroviÄiÄ‡_discontinuity" title="MohoroviÄiÄ‡ discontinuity" id="mwA8o">MohoroviÄiÄ‡ discontinuity</a>.<sup about="#mwt745" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-GeolSoc_135-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"GeolSoc"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-GeolSoc-135" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 127;" id="mwA8s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8w">[127]</span></a></sup> The thickness of the crust varies from about <span about="#mwt743" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"6"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA80">6 kilometers (3.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt743">Â </span><span about="#mwt743">mi)</span> under the oceans to <span about="#mwt744" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"-"},"3":{"wt":"50"},"4":{"wt":"km"},"5":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA84">30â€“50</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt744">Â </span><span about="#mwt744">km (19â€“31</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt744">Â </span><span about="#mwt744">mi)</span> for the continents. The crust and the cold, rigid, top of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_mantle" title="Upper mantle" id="mwA88">upper mantle</a> are collectively known as the lithosphere, which is divided into independently moving tectonic plates.<sup about="#mwt749" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-136" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-136"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-136" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 128;" id="mwA9A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9E">[128]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA9I">Beneath the lithosphere is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Asthenosphere" title="Asthenosphere" id="mwA9M">asthenosphere</a>, a relatively low-viscosity layer on which the lithosphere rides. Important changes in crystal structure within the mantle occur at <span about="#mwt752" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"410"},"2":{"wt":"and"},"3":{"wt":"660"},"4":{"wt":"km"},"5":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA9Q">410 and 660</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt752">Â </span><span about="#mwt752">km (250 and 410</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt752">Â </span><span about="#mwt752">mi)</span> below the surface, spanning a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Transition_zone_(Earth)" title="Transition zone (Earth)" id="mwA9U">transition zone</a> that separates the upper and lower mantle. Beneath the mantle, an extremely low viscosity liquid <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Outer_core" title="Outer core" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA9Y">outer core</a> lies above a solid <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_inner_core" title="Earth's inner core" id="mwA9c">inner core</a>.<sup about="#mwt753" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-tanimoto_ahrens1995_137-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"tanimoto_ahrens1995"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-tanimoto_ahrens1995-137" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 129;" id="mwA9g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9k">[129]</span></a></sup> Earth's inner core may be rotating at a slightly higher <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Angular_velocity" title="Angular velocity" id="mwA9o">angular velocity</a> than the remainder of the planet, advancing by 0.1â€“0.5Â° per year, although both somewhat higher and much lower rates have also been proposed.<sup about="#mwt754" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Deuss_2014_138-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Deuss_2014"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Deuss_2014-138" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 130;" id="mwA9s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9w">[130]</span></a></sup> The radius of the inner core is about one-fifth of that of Earth.
<span class="anchor" id="Density" about="#mwt755" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"anchor","href":"./Template:Anchor"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Density"}},"i":0}}]}'></span>Density increases with depth, as described in the table on the right.</p>

<p id="mwA90">Among the Solar System's planetary-sized objects Earth is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_solar_system_objects_by_size" title="List of solar system objects by size" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA94">object with the highest density</a>.</p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="12" id="mwA98"><h3 id="Chemical_composition">Chemical composition</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt756" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Abundance of elements on Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA-A"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt756" id="mwA-E">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abundance_of_elements_on_Earth" title="Abundance of elements on Earth" class="mw-redirect">Abundance of elements on Earth</a></div>

<p id="mwA-I"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_mass" title="Earth mass" id="mwA-M">Earth's mass</a> is approximately <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt763" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"5.97"},"e":{"wt":"24"},"ul":{"wt":"kg"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA-Q"><span data-sort-value="7024597000000000000â™ "></span>5.97<span style="margin-left:0.25em;margin-right:0.15em;">Ã—</span>10<sup>24</sup><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kilogram" title="Kilogram">kg</a></span> (5,970 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Yottagram" title="Yottagram" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA-U">Yg</a>). It is composed mostly of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iron" title="Iron" id="mwA-Y">iron</a> (32.1% <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mass_fraction_(chemistry)" title="Mass fraction (chemistry)" id="mwA-c">by mass</a>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxygen" title="Oxygen" id="mwA-g">oxygen</a> (30.1%), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silicon" title="Silicon" id="mwA-k">silicon</a> (15.1%), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magnesium" title="Magnesium" id="mwA-o">magnesium</a> (13.9%), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sulfur" title="Sulfur" id="mwA-s">sulfur</a> (2.9%), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nickel" title="Nickel" id="mwA-w">nickel</a> (1.8%), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Calcium" title="Calcium" id="mwA-0">calcium</a> (1.5%), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aluminum" title="Aluminum" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA-4">aluminum</a> (1.4%), with the remaining 1.2% consisting of trace amounts of other elements. Due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_differentiation#Gravitational_separation" title="Planetary differentiation" id="mwA-8">gravitational separation</a>, the core is primarily composed of the denser elements: iron (88.8%), with smaller amounts of nickel (5.8%), sulfur (4.5%), and less than 1% trace elements.<sup about="#mwt764" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pnas71_12_6973_139-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pnas71_12_6973"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-pnas71_12_6973-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 131;" id="mwA_A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_E">[131]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt765" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-comp_53-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"comp"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-comp-53" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwA_I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_M">[49]</span></a></sup> The most common rock constituents of the crust are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxide" title="Oxide" id="mwA_Q">oxides</a>. Over 99% of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_crust" title="Earth's crust" id="mwA_U">crust</a> is composed of various oxides of eleven elements, principally oxides containing silicon (the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silicate_mineral" title="Silicate mineral" id="mwA_Y">silicate minerals</a>), aluminum, iron, calcium, magnesium, potassium, or sodium.<sup about="#mwt766" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brown_mussett1981_140-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brown_mussett1981"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-brown_mussett1981-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwA_c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_g">[132]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt767" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pnas71_12_6973_139-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pnas71_12_6973"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-pnas71_12_6973-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 131;" id="mwA_k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_o">[131]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="13" id="mwA_s"><h3 id="Internal_heat">Internal heat</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt768" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s internal heat budget"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA_w"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt768" id="mwA_0">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_internal_heat_budget" title="Earth's internal heat budget">Earth's internal heat budget</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA_4"><a href="./File:Earth_heat_flow.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA_8"><img resource="./File:Earth_heat_flow.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Earth_heat_flow.jpg/260px-Earth_heat_flow.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="750" data-file-type="bitmap" height="195" width="260" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Earth_heat_flow.jpg/390px-Earth_heat_flow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Earth_heat_flow.jpg/520px-Earth_heat_flow.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBAA"/></a><figcaption id="mwBAE">Global map of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heat_flow" title="Heat flow" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAI">heat flow</a> from Earth's interior to the surface of Earth's crust, mostly along the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_ridge" title="Oceanic ridge" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAM">oceanic ridges</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBAQ">The major heat-producing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Isotope" title="Isotope" id="mwBAU">isotopes</a> within Earth are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Potassium-40" title="Potassium-40" id="mwBAY">potassium-40</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uranium-238" title="Uranium-238" id="mwBAc">uranium-238</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thorium-232" title="Thorium-232" id="mwBAg">thorium-232</a>.<sup about="#mwt779" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sanders20031210_141-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sanders20031210"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sanders20031210-141" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 133;" id="mwBAk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBAo">[133]</span></a></sup> At the center, the temperature may be up to <span about="#mwt776" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"6000"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBAs">6,000</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt776">Â </span><span about="#mwt776">Â°C (10,830</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt776">Â </span><span about="#mwt776">Â°F)</span>,<sup about="#mwt783" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-142" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-142"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-142" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 134;" id="mwBAw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBA0">[134]</span></a></sup> and the pressure could reach <span about="#mwt777" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"360"},"2":{"wt":"GPa"},"3":{"wt":"e6psi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"},"lk":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBA4">360</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt777">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pascal_(unit)" title="Pascal (unit)" about="#mwt777">GPa</a><span about="#mwt777"> (52</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt777">Â </span><span about="#mwt777">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt777">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pound_per_square_inch" title="Pound per square inch" about="#mwt777">psi</a><span about="#mwt777">)</span>.<sup about="#mwt784" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ptrsl360_1795_1227_143-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ptrsl360_1795_1227"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ptrsl360_1795_1227-143" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 135;" id="mwBA8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBA">[135]</span></a></sup> Because much of the heat is provided by radioactive decay, scientists postulate that early in Earth's history, before isotopes with short half-lives were depleted, Earth's heat production was much higher. At approximately <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt778" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3"},"ul":{"wt":"Gyr"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBBE"><span data-sort-value="7016946728000000000â™ "></span>3<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Billion_years" title="Billion years" class="mw-redirect">Gyr</a></span>, twice the present-day heat would have been produced, increasing the rates of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mantle_convection" title="Mantle convection" id="mwBBI">mantle convection</a> and plate tectonics, and allowing the production of uncommon <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Igneous_rock" title="Igneous rock" id="mwBBM">igneous rocks</a> such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Komatiite" title="Komatiite" id="mwBBQ">komatiites</a> that are rarely formed today.<sup about="#mwt785" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-T&amp;S_137_144-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"T&amp;S 137"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-T&amp;S_137-144" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 136;" id="mwBBU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBY">[136]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt786" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-epsl121_1_145-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"epsl121_1"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-epsl121_1-145" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 137;" id="mwBBc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBg">[137]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBBk">The mean heat loss from Earth is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt790" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"87"},"u":{"wt":"mW m&lt;sup>âˆ’2&lt;/sup>"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBBo"><span data-sort-value="7001870000000000000â™ "></span>87<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>mW m<sup>âˆ’2</sup></span>, for a global heat loss of <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt791" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4.42"},"e":{"wt":"13"},"u":{"wt":"W"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBBs"><span data-sort-value="7013442000000000000â™ "></span>4.42<span style="margin-left:0.25em;margin-right:0.15em;">Ã—</span>10<sup>13</sup><span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>W</span>.<sup about="#mwt792" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jg31_3_267_146-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jg31_3_267"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-jg31_3_267-146" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwBBw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBB0">[138]</span></a></sup> A portion of the core's thermal energy is transported toward the crust by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mantle_plume" title="Mantle plume" id="mwBB4">mantle plumes</a>, a form of convection consisting of upwellings of higher-temperature rock. These plumes can produce <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hotspot_(geology)" title="Hotspot (geology)" id="mwBB8">hotspots</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flood_basalt" title="Flood basalt" id="mwBCA">flood basalts</a>.<sup about="#mwt793" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-science246_4926_103_147-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"science246_4926_103"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-science246_4926_103-147" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwBCE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCI">[139]</span></a></sup> More of the heat in Earth is lost through plate tectonics, by mantle upwelling associated with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mid-ocean_ridge" title="Mid-ocean ridge" id="mwBCM">mid-ocean ridges</a>.
