The final major mode of heat loss is through conduction through the lithosphere, the majority of which occurs under the oceans because the crust there is much thinner than that of the continents.<sup about="#mwt794" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-heat_loss_148-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"heat loss"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-heat_loss-148" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 140;" id="mwBCQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCU">[140]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="14" id="mwBCY"><h3 id="Gravitational_field">Gravitational field</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt795" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Gravity of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBCc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt795" id="mwBCg">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravity_of_Earth" title="Gravity of Earth">Gravity of Earth</a></div>
<p id="mwBCk">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravity_of_Earth" title="Gravity of Earth" id="mwBCo">gravity of Earth</a> is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acceleration" title="Acceleration" id="mwBCs">acceleration</a> that is imparted to objects due to the distribution of mass within Earth. Near Earth's surface, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravitational_acceleration" title="Gravitational acceleration" id="mwBCw">gravitational acceleration</a> is approximately <span about="#mwt799" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"9.8"},"2":{"wt":"m/s2"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBC0">9.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt799">Â </span><span about="#mwt799">m/s</span><sup about="#mwt799">2</sup><span about="#mwt799"> (32</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt799">Â </span><span about="#mwt799">ft/s</span><sup about="#mwt799">2</sup><span about="#mwt799">)</span>. Local differences in topography, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geology" title="Geology" id="mwBC4">geology</a>, and deeper tectonic structure cause local and broad regional differences in Earth's gravitational field, known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravity_anomaly" title="Gravity anomaly" id="mwBC8">gravity anomalies</a>.<sup about="#mwt803" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-149" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-149"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 141;" id="mwBDA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBDE">[141]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="15" id="mwBDI"><h3 id="Magnetic_field">Magnetic field</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt804" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s magnetic field"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBDM"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt804" id="mwBDQ">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field">Earth's magnetic field</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBDU"><a href="./File:Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBDY"><img alt="Diagram showing the magnetic field lines of Earth's magnetosphere. The lines are swept back in the anti-solar direction under the influence of the solar wind." resource="./File:Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg/220px-Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="330" data-file-height="353" data-file-type="drawing" height="235" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg/330px-Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg/440px-Magnetosphere_Levels-en.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBDc"/></a><figcaption id="mwBDg">Schematic of Earth's magnetosphere, with the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_wind" title="Solar wind" id="mwBDk">solar wind</a> flows from left to right</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBDo">The main part of Earth's magnetic field is generated in the core, the site of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dynamo_theory" title="Dynamo theory" id="mwBDs">dynamo</a> process that converts the kinetic energy of thermally and compositionally driven convection into electrical and magnetic field energy. The field extends outwards from the core, through the mantle, and up to Earth's surface, where it is, approximately, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dipole" title="Dipole" id="mwBDw">dipole</a>. The poles of the dipole are located close to Earth's geographic poles. At the equator of the magnetic field, the magnetic-field strength at the surface is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt810" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3.05{{e|âˆ’5}} [[Tesla (unit)|T]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBD0">3.05<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">Ã—</span>10<sup>âˆ’5</sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tesla_(unit)" title="Tesla (unit)">T</a></span>, with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magnetic_dipole_moment" title="Magnetic dipole moment" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBD4">magnetic dipole moment</a> of <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt811" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"7.79{{e|22}} Am{{sup|2}}"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBD8">7.79<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">Ã—</span>10<sup><span class="nowrap"><span data-sort-value="7001220000000000000â™ "></span>22</span></sup> Am<sup>2</sup></span> at epoch 2000, decreasing nearly 6% per century (although it still remains stronger than its long time average).<sup about="#mwt815" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dipole_150-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dipole"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dipole-150"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-dipole-150" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 142;" id="mwBEA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEE">[142]</span></a></sup> The convection movements in the core are chaotic; the magnetic poles drift and periodically change alignment. This causes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geomagnetic_secular_variation" title="Geomagnetic secular variation" id="mwBEI">secular variation</a> of the main field and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geomagnetic_reversal" title="Geomagnetic reversal" id="mwBEM">field reversals</a> at irregular intervals averaging a few times every million years. The most recent reversal occurred approximately 700,000 years ago.<sup about="#mwt816" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fitzpatrick2006_151-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fitzpatrick2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-fitzpatrick2006-151" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 143;" id="mwBEQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEU">[143]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt817" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-campbelwh_152-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"campbelwh"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-campbelwh-152" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 144;" id="mwBEY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEc">[144]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBEg">The extent of Earth's magnetic field in space defines the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magnetosphere" title="Magnetosphere" id="mwBEk">magnetosphere</a>. Ions and electrons of the solar wind are deflected by the magnetosphere; solar wind pressure compresses the dayside of the magnetosphere, to about 10 Earth radii, and extends the nightside magnetosphere into a long tail.<sup about="#mwt828" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-153" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-153"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-153" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 145;" id="mwBEo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEs">[145]</span></a></sup> Because the velocity of the solar wind is greater than the speed at which waves propagate through the solar wind, a supersonic <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bow_shock" title="Bow shock" id="mwBEw">bow shock</a> precedes the dayside magnetosphere within the solar wind.<sup about="#mwt832" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-154" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-154"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 146;" id="mwBE0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBE4">[146]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charged_particle" title="Charged particle" id="mwBE8">Charged particles</a> are contained within the magnetosphere; the plasmasphere is defined by low-energy particles that essentially follow magnetic field lines as Earth rotates.<sup about="#mwt836" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-155" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-155"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-155" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 147;" id="mwBFA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFE">[147]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt840" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-156" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-156"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 148;" id="mwBFI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFM">[148]</span></a></sup> The ring current is defined by medium-energy particles that drift relative to the geomagnetic field, but with paths that are still dominated by the magnetic field,<sup about="#mwt844" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-BaumjohannTreumann1997_157-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"BaumjohannTreumann1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-BaumjohannTreumann1997-157"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-BaumjohannTreumann1997-157" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBFQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFU">[149]</span></a></sup> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Van_Allen_radiation_belt" title="Van Allen radiation belt" id="mwBFY">Van Allen radiation belts</a> are formed by high-energy particles whose motion is essentially random, but contained in the magnetosphere.<sup about="#mwt848" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_158-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Britannica"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Britannica-158"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Britannica-158" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 150;" id="mwBFc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFg">[150]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt852" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Van_Allen_159-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Van Allen"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Van_Allen-159"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Van_Allen-159" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 151;" id="mwBFk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFo">[151]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBFs">During <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magnetic_storm" title="Magnetic storm" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBFw">magnetic storms</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Substorm" title="Substorm" id="mwBF0">substorms</a>, charged particles can be deflected from the outer magnetosphere and especially the magnetotail, directed along field lines into Earth's ionosphere, where atmospheric atoms can be excited and ionized, causing the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aurora_(astronomy)" title="Aurora (astronomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBF4">aurora</a>.<sup about="#mwt854" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-stern2005_160-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"stern2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-stern2005-160" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 152;" id="mwBF8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBGA">[152]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="16" id="mwBGE"><h2 id="Orbit_and_rotation">Orbit and rotation</h2>
<section data-mw-section-id="17" id="mwBGI"><h3 id="Rotation">Rotation</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt855" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s rotation"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGM"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt855" id="mwBGQ">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_rotation" title="Earth's rotation">Earth's rotation</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBGU"><a href="./File:EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBGY"><img resource="./File:EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif/260px-EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif" decoding="async" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1500" data-file-type="bitmap" height="260" width="260" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif/390px-EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif/520px-EpicEarth-Globespin-tilt-23.4.gif 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBGc"/></a><figcaption id="mwBGg">Satellite <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Time-lapse_photography" title="Time-lapse photography" id="mwBGk">time lapse imagery</a> of Earth's rotation showing axis tilt</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBGo">Earth's rotation period relative to the Sunâ€”its mean solar dayâ€”is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt861" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"86,400 seconds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGs">86,400 seconds</span> of mean solar time (<span class="nowrap" about="#mwt862" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"86,400.0025 [[SI]] seconds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGw">86,400.0025 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./SI" title="SI" class="mw-redirect">SI</a> seconds</span>).<sup about="#mwt864" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-aj136_5_1906_161-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"aj136_5_1906"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-aj136_5_1906-161" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 153;" id="mwBG0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBG4">[153]</span></a></sup> Because Earth's solar day is now slightly longer than it was during the 19th century due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tidal_acceleration" title="Tidal acceleration" id="mwBG8">tidal deceleration</a>, each day varies between <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt863" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"0 and 2 [[millisecond|ms]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBHA">0 and 2 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Millisecond" title="Millisecond">ms</a></span> longer than the mean solar day.<sup about="#mwt865" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-USNO_TSD_162-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"USNO_TSD"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-USNO_TSD-162" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwBHE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHI">[154]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt869" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-163" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-163"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-163" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 155;" id="mwBHM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHQ">[155]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBHU">Earth's rotation period relative to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fixed_star" title="Fixed star" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBHY">fixed stars</a>, called its <i id="mwBHc">stellar day</i> by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./International_Earth_Rotation_and_Reference_Systems_Service" title="International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service" id="mwBHg">International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service</a> (IERS), is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt874" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"86,164.0989 seconds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBHk">86,164.0989 seconds</span> of mean solar time (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./UT1" title="UT1" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBHo">UT1</a>), or <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt875" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap ","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"23{{smallsup|h}} 56{{smallsup|m}} 4.0989{{smallsup|s}}."}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBHs">23<sup><small>h</small></sup> 56<sup><small>m</small></sup> 4.0989<sup><small>s</small></sup>.</span><sup about="#mwt878" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-IERS_4-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"IERS"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-IERS-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mwBHw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBH0">[2]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt879" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Aoki_164-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"group":"n","name":"Aoki"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Aoki-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwBH4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBH8">[n 9]</span></a></sup> Earth's rotation period relative to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Precession_(astronomy)" title="Precession (astronomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBIA">precessing</a> or moving mean <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./March_equinox" title="March equinox" id="mwBIE">March equinox</a> (when the Sun is at 90Â° on the equator)<!-- , misnamed its ''[[sidereal day]]'' [don't know what is this] -->, is <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt876" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"86,164.0905 seconds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBII">86,164.0905 seconds</span> of mean solar time (UT1) <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt877" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"nowrap","href":"./Template:Nowrap"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"(23{{smallsup|h}} 56{{smallsup|m}} 4.0905{{smallsup|s}})"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBIM">(23<sup><small>h</small></sup> 56<sup><small>m</small></sup> 4.0905<sup><small>s</small></sup>)</span>.<sup about="#mwt880" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-IERS_4-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"IERS"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-IERS-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mwBIQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIU">[2]</span></a></sup> Thus the sidereal day is shorter than the stellar day by about 8.4<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBIY">Â </span>ms.<sup about="#mwt881" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-seidelmann1992_165-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"seidelmann1992"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-seidelmann1992-165" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwBIc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIg">[156]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBIk">Apart from meteors within the atmosphere and low-orbiting satellites, the main apparent motion of celestial bodies in Earth's sky is to the west at a rate of 15Â°/h = 15'/min. For bodies near the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Celestial_equator" title="Celestial equator" id="mwBIo">celestial equator</a>, this is equivalent to an apparent diameter of the Sun or the Moon every two minutes; from Earth's surface, the apparent sizes of the Sun and the Moon are approximately the same.<sup about="#mwt884" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zeilik1998_166-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zeilik1998"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-zeilik1998-166" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 157;" id="mwBIs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIw">[157]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt885" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-angular_167-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"angular"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-angular-167" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 158;" id="mwBI0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBI4">[158]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="18" id="mwBI8"><h3 id="Orbit">Orbit</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt886" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s orbit"},"2":{"wt":"Earth&apos;s location"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBJA"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt886" id="mwBJE">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_orbit" title="Earth's orbit">Earth's orbit</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_location" title="Earth's location" class="mw-redirect">Earth's location</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBJI"><a href="./File:Seasons1.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBJM"><img resource="./File:Seasons1.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Seasons1.svg/510px-Seasons1.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1826" data-file-height="1070" data-file-type="drawing" height="299" width="510" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Seasons1.svg/765px-Seasons1.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Seasons1.svg/1020px-Seasons1.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBJQ"/></a><figcaption id="mwBJU">Exaggerated illustration of Earth's elliptical orbit around the Sun, marking that the orbital extreme points (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Apoapsis" title="Apoapsis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJY">apoapsis</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Periapsis" title="Periapsis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJc">periapsis</a>) are not the same as the four <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Season" title="Season" id="mwBJg">seasonal</a> extreme points (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Equinox" title="Equinox" id="mwBJk">equinox</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solstice" title="Solstice" id="mwBJo">solstice</a>)</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBJs">Earth orbits the Sun, making Earth the third-closest planet to the Sun and part of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Inner_Solar_System" title="Inner Solar System" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJw">inner Solar System</a>. Earth's average orbital distance is about <span about="#mwt889" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"150"},"2":{"wt":"e6km"},"3":{"wt":"e6mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBJ0">150</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt889">Â </span><span about="#mwt889">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt889">Â </span><span about="#mwt889">km (93</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt889">Â </span><span about="#mwt889">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt889">Â </span><span about="#mwt889">mi)</span>, which is the basis for the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Astronomical_Unit" title="Astronomical Unit" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJ4">Astronomical Unit</a> and is equal to roughly 8.3 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Light_minute" title="Light minute" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJ8">light minutes</a> or 380 times <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lunar_distance_(astronomy)" title="Lunar distance (astronomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBKA">Earth's distance to the Moon</a>.</p>

<p id="mwBKE">Earth orbits the Sun every 365.2564 mean <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_day" title="Solar day" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBKI">solar days</a>, or one <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sidereal_year" title="Sidereal year" id="mwBKM">sidereal year</a>. With an apparent movement of the Sun in Earth's sky at a rate of about 1Â°/day eastward, which is one apparent Sun or Moon diameter every 12<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBKQ">Â </span>hours. Due to this motion, on average it takes 24<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBKU">Â </span>hoursâ€”a solar dayâ€”for Earth to complete a full rotation about its axis so that the Sun returns to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meridian_(astronomy)" title="Meridian (astronomy)" id="mwBKY">meridian</a>.</p>

<p id="mwBKc">The orbital speed of Earth averages about <span about="#mwt891" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"29.78"},"2":{"wt":"km/s"},"3":{"wt":"km/h mph"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBKg">29.78</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt891">Â </span><span about="#mwt891">km/s (107,200</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt891">Â </span><span about="#mwt891">km/h; 66,600</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt891">Â </span><span about="#mwt891">mph)</span>, which is fast enough to travel a distance equal to Earth's diameter, about <span about="#mwt892" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"12742"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBKk">12,742</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt892">Â </span><span about="#mwt892">km (7,918</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt892">Â </span><span about="#mwt892">mi)</span>, in seven minutes, and the distance to the Moon, <span about="#mwt893" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"384000"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBKo">384,000</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt893">Â </span><span about="#mwt893">km (239,000</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt893">Â </span><span about="#mwt893">mi)</span>, in about 3.5 hours.<sup about="#mwt894" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-18" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"earth_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwBKs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKw">[3]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBK0">The Moon and Earth orbit a common <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Barycenter" title="Barycenter" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBK4">barycenter</a> every 27.32<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBK8">Â </span>days relative to the background stars. When combined with the Earthâ€“Moon system's common orbit around the Sun, the period of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synodic_month" title="Synodic month" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBLA">synodic month</a>, from new moon to new moon, is 29.53<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBLE">Â </span>days. Viewed from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Celestial_pole" title="Celestial pole" id="mwBLI">celestial north pole</a>, the motion of Earth, the Moon, and their axial rotations are all <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Counterclockwise" title="Counterclockwise" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBLM">counterclockwise</a>. Viewed from a vantage point above the Sun and Earth's north poles, Earth orbits in a counterclockwise direction about the Sun. The orbital and axial planes are not precisely aligned: Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Axial_tilt" title="Axial tilt" id="mwBLQ">axis is tilted</a> some 23.44 degrees from the perpendicular to the Earthâ€“Sun plane (the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecliptic" title="Ecliptic" id="mwBLU">ecliptic</a>), and the Earth-Moon plane is tilted up to Â±5.1 degrees against the Earthâ€“Sun plane. Without this tilt, there would be an eclipse every two weeks, alternating between <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lunar_eclipse" title="Lunar eclipse" id="mwBLY">lunar eclipses</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse" id="mwBLc">solar eclipses</a>.<sup about="#mwt897" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-19" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"earth_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwBLg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLk">[3]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt898" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-moon_fact_sheet_168-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"moon_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-moon_fact_sheet-168" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 159;" id="mwBLo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLs">[159]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBLw">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hill_sphere" title="Hill sphere" id="mwBL0">Hill sphere</a>, or the sphere of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravity" title="Gravity" id="mwBL4">gravitational</a> influence, of Earth is about <span about="#mwt903" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.5"},"2":{"wt":"e6km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBL8">1.5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt903">Â </span><span about="#mwt903">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt903">Â </span><span about="#mwt903">km (930,000</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt903">Â </span><span about="#mwt903">mi)</span> in radius.<sup about="#mwt904" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-vazquez_etal2006_169-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"vazquez_etal2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-vazquez_etal2006-169" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 160;" id="mwBMA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBME">[160]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt905" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hill_radius_170-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"group":"n","name":"hill_radius"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-hill_radius-170" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwBMI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMM">[n 10]</span></a></sup> This is the maximum distance at which Earth's gravitational influence is stronger than the more distant Sun and planets. Objects must orbit Earth within this radius, or they can become unbound by the gravitational perturbation of the Sun.<sup about="#mwt906" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-vazquez_etal2006_169-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"vazquez_etal2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-vazquez_etal2006-169" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 160;" id="mwBMQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMU">[160]</span></a></sup> Earth, along with the Solar System, is situated in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Milky_Way" title="Milky Way" id="mwBMY">Milky Way</a> and orbits about 28,000<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBMc">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Light-year" title="Light-year" id="mwBMg">light-years</a> from its center. It is about 20<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBMk">Â </span>light-years above the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Galactic_plane" title="Galactic plane" id="mwBMo">galactic plane</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Orion_Arm" title="Orion Arm" id="mwBMs">Orion Arm</a>.<sup about="#mwt907" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-nasa20051201_171-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"nasa20051201"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-nasa20051201-171" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 161;" id="mwBMw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBM0">[161]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="19" id="mwBM4"><h3 id="Axial_tilt_and_seasons">Axial tilt and seasons</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt908" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Axial tilt#Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBM8"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt908" id="mwBNA">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Axial_tilt#Earth" title="Axial tilt">Axial tilt Â§<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Earth</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBNE"><a href="./File:Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBNI"><img resource="./File:Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg/400px-Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="186" data-file-type="drawing" height="145" width="400" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg/600px-Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg/800px-Axial_tilt_vs_tropical_and_polar_circles.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBNM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBNQ">Earth's axial tilt causing different angles of seasonal illumination at different orbital positions around the Sun</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBNU">The axial tilt of Earth is approximately 23.439281Â°<sup about="#mwt915" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-IERS_4-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"IERS"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-IERS-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mwBNY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBNc">[2]</span></a></sup> with the axis of its orbit plane, always pointing towards the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Celestial_Poles" title="Celestial Poles" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBNg">Celestial Poles</a>. Due to Earth's axial tilt, the amount of sunlight reaching any given point on the surface varies over the course of the year. This causes the seasonal change in climate, with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Summer" title="Summer" id="mwBNk">summer</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere" id="mwBNo">Northern Hemisphere</a> occurring when the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer" id="mwBNs">Tropic of Cancer</a> is facing the Sun, and in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere" id="mwBNw">Southern Hemisphere</a> when the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropic_of_Capricorn" title="Tropic of Capricorn" id="mwBN0">Tropic of Capricorn</a> faces the Sun. In each instance, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Winter" title="Winter" id="mwBN4">winter</a> occurs simultaneously in the opposite hemisphere. During the summer, the day lasts longer, and the Sun climbs higher in the sky. In winter, the climate becomes cooler and the days shorter.<sup about="#mwt919" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-172" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-172"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-172" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 162;" id="mwBN8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOA">[162]</span></a></sup> Above the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arctic_Circle" title="Arctic Circle" id="mwBOE">Arctic Circle</a> and below the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_Circle" title="Antarctic Circle" id="mwBOI">Antarctic Circle</a> there is no daylight at all for part of the year, causing a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_night" title="Polar night" id="mwBOM">polar night</a>, and this night extends for several months at the poles themselves. These same latitudes also experience a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Midnight_sun" title="Midnight sun" id="mwBOQ">midnight sun</a>, where the sun remains visible all day.<sup about="#mwt923" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-173" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-173"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-173" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 163;" id="mwBOU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOY">[163]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt927" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-174" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-174"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-174" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwBOc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOg">[164]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBOk">By astronomical convention, the four seasons can be determined by the solsticesâ€”the points in the orbit of maximum axial tilt toward or away from the Sunâ€”and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Equinox" title="Equinox" id="mwBOo">equinoxes</a>, when Earth's rotational axis is aligned with its orbital axis. In the Northern Hemisphere, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Winter_solstice" title="Winter solstice" id="mwBOs">winter solstice</a> currently occurs around 21 December; <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Summer_solstice" title="Summer solstice" id="mwBOw">summer solstice</a> is near 21 June, spring equinox is around 20 March and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./September_equinox" title="September equinox" id="mwBO0">autumnal equinox</a> is about 22 or 23 September. In the Southern Hemisphere, the situation is reversed, with the summer and winter solstices exchanged and the spring and autumnal equinox dates swapped.<sup about="#mwt929" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bromberg2008_175-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bromberg2008"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-bromberg2008-175" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 165;" id="mwBO4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBO8">[165]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBPA">The angle of Earth's axial tilt is relatively stable over long periods of time. Its axial tilt does undergo <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nutation" title="Nutation" id="mwBPE">nutation</a>; a slight, irregular motion with a main period of 18.6<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBPI">Â </span>years.<sup about="#mwt932" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lin2006_176-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lin2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-lin2006-176" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 166;" id="mwBPM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPQ">[166]</span></a></sup> The orientation (rather than the angle) of Earth's axis also changes over time, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Axial_precession" title="Axial precession" id="mwBPU">precessing</a> around in a complete circle over each 25,800-year cycle; this precession is the reason for the difference between a sidereal year and a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropical_year" title="Tropical year" id="mwBPY">tropical year</a>. Both of these motions are caused by the varying attraction of the Sun and the Moon on Earth's equatorial bulge. The poles also migrate a few meters across Earth's surface. This <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_motion" title="Polar motion" id="mwBPc">polar motion</a> has multiple, cyclical components, which collectively are termed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quasiperiodic_motion" title="Quasiperiodic motion" id="mwBPg">quasiperiodic motion</a>. In addition to an annual component to this motion, there is a 14-month cycle called the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chandler_wobble" title="Chandler wobble" id="mwBPk">Chandler wobble</a>. Earth's rotational velocity also varies in a phenomenon known as length-of-day variation.<sup about="#mwt933" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fisher19960205_177-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fisher19960205"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-fisher19960205-177" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 167;" id="mwBPo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPs">[167]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBPw">In modern times, Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Perihelion" title="Perihelion" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBP0">perihelion</a> occurs around 3 January, and its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aphelion" title="Aphelion" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBP4">aphelion</a> around 4 July. These dates change over time due to precession and other orbital factors, which follow cyclical patterns known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Milankovitch_cycles" title="Milankovitch cycles" id="mwBP8">Milankovitch cycles</a>. The changing Earthâ€“Sun distance causes an increase of about 6.8% in solar energy reaching Earth at perihelion relative to aphelion.<sup about="#mwt940" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-178" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-178"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-178" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 168;" id="mwBQA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQE">[168]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt941" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-solar_energy_179-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"group":"n","name":"solar_energy"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-solar_energy-179" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwBQI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQM">[n 11]</span></a></sup> Because the Southern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun at about the same time that Earth reaches the closest approach to the Sun, the Southern Hemisphere receives slightly more energy from the Sun than does the northern over the course of a year. This effect is much less significant than the total energy change due to the axial tilt, and most of the excess energy is absorbed by the higher proportion of water in the Southern Hemisphere.<sup about="#mwt945" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-180" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-180"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-180" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 169;" id="mwBQQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQU">[169]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="20" id="mwBQY"><h2 id="Earthâ€“Moon_system"><span id="Earth.E2.80.93Moon_system" typeof="mw:FallbackId"></span>Earthâ€“Moon system</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt946" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":""},"2":{"wt":"Satellite system (astronomy)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBQc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt946" id="mwBQg">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Satellite_system_(astronomy)" title="Satellite system (astronomy)">Satellite system (astronomy)</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="21" id="mwBQk"><h3 id="Moon">Moon</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt949" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Moon"},"2":{"wt":"Lunar theory"},"3":{"wt":"Orbit of the Moon"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBQo"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt949" id="mwBQs">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lunar_theory" title="Lunar theory">Lunar theory</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Orbit_of_the_Moon" title="Orbit of the Moon">Orbit of the Moon</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBQw"><a href="./File:MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBQ0"><img resource="./File:MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg/220px-MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="800" data-file-type="bitmap" height="220" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg/330px-MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg/440px-MarsReconnaissanceOrbiter-Views-EarthMoon-20220422.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBQ4"/></a><figcaption id="mwBQ8">Earth and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Moon" title="Moon" id="mwBRA">Moon</a> as seen from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mars" title="Mars" id="mwBRE">Mars</a> in an image taken by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./NASA" title="NASA" id="mwBRI">NASA</a>'s <i id="mwBRM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mars_Reconnaissance_Orbiter" title="Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter" id="mwBRQ">Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter</a></i> on 22 April 2022</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBRU">The Moon is a relatively large, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet" id="mwBRY">terrestrial</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary-mass_moon" title="Planetary-mass moon" id="mwBRc">planet-like natural satellite</a>, with a diameter about one-quarter of Earth's. It is the largest moon in the Solar System relative to the size of its planet, although <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charon_(moon)" title="Charon (moon)" id="mwBRg">Charon</a> is larger relative to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dwarf_planet" title="Dwarf planet" id="mwBRk">dwarf planet</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pluto" title="Pluto" id="mwBRo">Pluto</a>.<sup about="#mwt959" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-181" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-181"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-181" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 170;" id="mwBRs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRw">[170]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt963" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-182" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-182"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-182" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 171;" id="mwBR0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBR4">[171]</span></a></sup> The natural satellites of other planets are also referred to as "moons", after Earth's.<sup about="#mwt967" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-183" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-183"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-183" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 172;" id="mwBR8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSA">[172]</span></a></sup> The most widely accepted theory of the Moon's origin, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giant-impact_hypothesis" title="Giant-impact hypothesis" id="mwBSE">giant-impact hypothesis</a>, states that it formed from the collision of a Mars-size protoplanet called Theia with the early Earth. This hypothesis explains the Moon's relative lack of iron and volatile elements and the fact that its composition is nearly identical to that of Earth's crust.<sup about="#mwt968" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-canup_asphaug2001b_44-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"canup_asphaug2001b"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-canup_asphaug2001b-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwBSI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSM">[40]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBSQ">The gravitational attraction between Earth and the Moon causes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tide" title="Tide" id="mwBSU">tides</a> on Earth.<sup about="#mwt979" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-184" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-184"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-184" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 173;" id="mwBSY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSc">[173]</span></a></sup> The same effect on the Moon has led to its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tidal_locking" title="Tidal locking" id="mwBSg">tidal locking</a>: its rotation period is the same as the time it takes to orbit Earth. As a result, it always presents the same face to the planet.<sup about="#mwt983" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-185" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-185"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-185" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 174;" id="mwBSk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSo">[174]</span></a></sup> As the Moon orbits Earth, different parts of its face are illuminated by the Sun, leading to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lunar_phase" title="Lunar phase" id="mwBSs">lunar phases</a>.<sup about="#mwt987" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-186" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-186"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-186" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 175;" id="mwBSw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBS0">[175]</span></a></sup> Due to their tidal interaction, the Moon recedes from Earth at the rate of approximately <span about="#mwt974" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"38"},"2":{"wt":"mm/yr"},"3":{"wt":"in/yr"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBS4">38</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt974">Â </span><span about="#mwt974">mm/a (1.5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt974">Â </span><span about="#mwt974">in/year)</span>. Over millions of years, these tiny modificationsâ€”and the lengthening of Earth's day by about 23<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBS8">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microsecond" title="Microsecond" id="mwBTA">Âµs</a>/yrâ€”add up to significant changes.<sup about="#mwt988" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-espenak_meeus20070207_187-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"espenak_meeus20070207"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-espenak_meeus20070207-187" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 176;" id="mwBTE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTI">[176]</span></a></sup> During the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ediacaran" title="Ediacaran" id="mwBTM">Ediacaran</a> period, for example, (approximately <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt975" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"620"},"u":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBTQ"><span data-sort-value="7016195657120000000â™ "></span>620<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Ma</span>) there were 400Â±7 days in a year, with each day lasting 21.9Â±0.4 hours.<sup about="#mwt992" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-188" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-188"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-188" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 177;" id="mwBTU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTY">[177]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBTc">The Moon may have dramatically affected the development of life by moderating the planet's climate. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleontology" title="Paleontology" id="mwBTg">Paleontological</a> evidence and computer simulations show that Earth's axial tilt is stabilized by tidal interactions with the Moon.<sup about="#mwt996" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-aaa428_261_189-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"aaa428_261"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-aaa428_261-189" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 178;" id="mwBTk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTo">[178]</span></a></sup> Some theorists think that without this stabilization against the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Torque" title="Torque" id="mwBTs">torques</a> applied by the Sun and planets to Earth's equatorial bulge, the rotational axis might be chaotically unstable, exhibiting large changes over millions of years, as is the case for Mars, though this is disputed.<sup about="#mwt1000" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-190" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-190"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-190" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 179;" id="mwBTw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBT0">[179]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1004" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-191" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-191"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-191" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 180;" id="mwBT4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBT8">[180]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBUA">Viewed from Earth, the Moon is just far enough away to have almost the same apparent-sized disk as the Sun. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Angular_size" title="Angular size" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBUE">angular size</a> (or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solid_angle" title="Solid angle" id="mwBUI">solid angle</a>) of these two bodies match because, although the Sun's diameter is about 400 times as large as the Moon's, it is also 400 times more distant.<sup about="#mwt1007" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-angular_167-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"angular"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-angular-167" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 158;" id="mwBUM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBUQ">[158]</span></a></sup> This allows total and annular solar eclipses to occur on Earth.<sup about="#mwt1011" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-192" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-192"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-192" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 181;" id="mwBUU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBUY">[181]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="22" id="mwBUc"><h3 id="Asteroids_and_artificial_satellites">Asteroids and artificial satellites</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1012" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Near-Earth object"},"2":{"wt":"Claimed moons of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBUg"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1012" id="mwBUk">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Near-Earth_object" title="Near-Earth object">Near-Earth object</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Claimed_moons_of_Earth" title="Claimed moons of Earth">Claimed moons of Earth</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBUo"><a href="./File:Debris-GEO1280.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBUs"><img resource="./File:Debris-GEO1280.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Debris-GEO1280.jpg/220px-Debris-GEO1280.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="1024" data-file-type="bitmap" height="176" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Debris-GEO1280.jpg/330px-Debris-GEO1280.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Debris-GEO1280.jpg/440px-Debris-GEO1280.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBUw"/></a><figcaption id="mwBU0">A computer-generated image mapping the prevalence of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artificial_satellite" title="Artificial satellite" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBU4">artificial satellites</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Space_debris" title="Space debris" id="mwBU8">space debris</a> around Earth in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geosynchronous_orbit" title="Geosynchronous orbit" id="mwBVA">geosynchronous</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit" id="mwBVE">low Earth orbit</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBVI">Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Co-orbital_configuration" title="Co-orbital configuration" id="mwBVM">co-orbital asteroids</a> population consists of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quasi-satellite" title="Quasi-satellite" id="mwBVQ">quasi-satellites</a>, objects with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horseshoe_orbit" title="Horseshoe orbit" id="mwBVU">horseshoe orbit</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trojan_(celestial_body)" title="Trojan (celestial body)" id="mwBVY">trojans</a>. There are at least five quasi-satellites, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./469219_KamoÊ»oalewa" title="469219 KamoÊ»oalewa" id="mwBVc">469219 KamoÊ»oalewa</a>.<sup about="#mwt1021" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-christou_asher2011_193-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"christou_asher2011"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-christou_asher2011-193" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 182;" id="mwBVg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBVk">[182]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1025" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-194" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-194"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-194" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 183;" id="mwBVo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBVs">[183]</span></a></sup> A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_trojan" title="Earth trojan" id="mwBVw">trojan asteroid</a> companion, <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt1019" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"mpl","href":"./Template:Mpl"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2010 TK"},"2":{"wt":"7"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBV0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./2010_TK7" title="2010 TK7">2010 TK<span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;"><span style="font-size:80%;">7</span></span></a></span>, is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Libration" title="Libration" id="mwBV4">librating</a> around the leading <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagrangian_point" title="Lagrangian point" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBV8">Lagrange triangular point</a>, L4, in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_orbit" title="Earth's orbit" id="mwBWA">Earth's orbit</a> around the Sun.<sup about="#mwt1026" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Choi_195-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Choi"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Choi-195" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 184;" id="mwBWE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWI">[184]</span></a></sup> The tiny <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Near-Earth_asteroid" title="Near-Earth asteroid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBWM">near-Earth asteroid</a> <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt1020" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"mpl","href":"./Template:Mpl"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2006 RH"},"2":{"wt":"120"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBWQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./2006_RH120" title="2006 RH120">2006 RH<span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;"><span style="font-size:80%;">120</span></span></a></span> makes close approaches to the Earthâ€“Moon system roughly every twenty years. During these approaches, it can orbit Earth for brief periods of time.<sup about="#mwt1030" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-196" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-196"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-196" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 185;" id="mwBWU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWY">[185]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBWc"><span about="#mwt1034" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"As of","href":"./Template:As_of"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2021"},"2":{"wt":"9"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBWg">As of September</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1034">Â </span><span about="#mwt1034">2021</span><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;" about="#mwt1034"><a rel="mw:ExtLink" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Earth&amp;action=edit" class="external text"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>update<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></sup><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt1034"></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements_from_September_2021" about="#mwt1034"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements" about="#mwt1034" id="mwBWk"/>, there are 4,550 operational, human-made <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Satellite" title="Satellite" id="mwBWo">satellites</a> orbiting Earth.<sup about="#mwt1036" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ucs_197-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ucs"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ucs-197" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 186;" id="mwBWs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWw">[186]</span></a></sup> There are also inoperative satellites, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vanguard_1" title="Vanguard 1" id="mwBW0">Vanguard 1</a>, the oldest satellite currently in orbit, and over 16,000 pieces of tracked <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Space_debris" title="Space debris" id="mwBW4">space debris</a>.<sup about="#mwt1037" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-space_debris_198-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"group":"n","name":"space_debris"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-space_debris-198" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 12;" data-mw-group="n" id="mwBW8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBXA">[n 12]</span></a></sup> Earth's largest artificial satellite is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station" id="mwBXE">International Space Station</a>.<sup about="#mwt1041" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-199" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-199"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-199" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 187;" id="mwBXI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBXM">[187]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="23" id="mwBXQ"><h2 id="Hydrosphere">Hydrosphere</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1042" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Hydrosphere"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBXU"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1042" id="mwBXY">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrosphere" title="Hydrosphere">Hydrosphere</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBXc"><a href="./File:Ocean_world_Earth.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBXg"><img resource="./File:Ocean_world_Earth.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ocean_world_Earth.jpg/220px-Ocean_world_Earth.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2300" data-file-height="2300" data-file-type="bitmap" height="220" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ocean_world_Earth.jpg/330px-Ocean_world_Earth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ocean_world_Earth.jpg/440px-Ocean_world_Earth.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBXk"/></a><figcaption id="mwBXo">A view of Earth with its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Global_ocean" title="Global ocean" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBXs">global ocean</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloud_cover" title="Cloud cover" id="mwBXw">cloud cover</a>, which dominate Earth's surface and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrosphere" title="Hydrosphere" id="mwBX0">hydrosphere</a>. At Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_regions_of_Earth" title="Polar regions of Earth" id="mwBX4">polar</a> regions, its hydrosphere forms larger areas of ice cover</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBX8">Earth's hydrosphere is the sum of Earth's water and its distribution.
Most of Earth's hydrosphere consists of Earth's global <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean" title="Ocean" id="mwBYA">ocean</a>. Nevertheless, Earth's hydrosphere also consists of water in the atmosphere and on land, including clouds, inland seas, lakes, rivers, and underground waters down to a depth of <span about="#mwt1053" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2000"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYE">2,000</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1053">Â </span><span about="#mwt1053">m (6,600</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1053">Â </span><span about="#mwt1053">ft)</span>. The mass of the oceans is approximately 1.35<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em" about="#mwt1054" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"e","href":"./Template:E"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"18"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYI">Ã—</span><span about="#mwt1054">10</span><sup about="#mwt1054" id="mwBYM"><span class="nowrap"><span data-sort-value="7001180000000000000â™ "></span>18</span></sup><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBYQ">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metric_ton" title="Metric ton" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBYU">metric tons</a> or about 1/4400 of Earth's total mass. The oceans cover an area of <span about="#mwt1055" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"361.8"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6mi2"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYY">361.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1055">Â </span><span about="#mwt1055">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1055">Â </span><span about="#mwt1055">km</span><sup about="#mwt1055">2</sup><span about="#mwt1055"> (139.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1055">Â </span><span about="#mwt1055">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1055">Â </span><span about="#mwt1055">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1055">Â </span><span about="#mwt1055">mi)</span> with a mean depth of <span about="#mwt1056" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3682"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYc">3,682</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1056">Â </span><span about="#mwt1056">m (12,080</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1056">Â </span><span about="#mwt1056">ft)</span>, resulting in an estimated volume of <span about="#mwt1057" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.332"},"2":{"wt":"e9km3"},"3":{"wt":"e6cumi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYg">1.332</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1057">Â </span><span about="#mwt1057">billion</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1057">Â </span><span about="#mwt1057">km</span><sup about="#mwt1057">3</sup><span about="#mwt1057"> (320</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1057">Â </span><span about="#mwt1057">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1057">Â </span><span about="#mwt1057">cu</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1057">Â </span><span about="#mwt1057">mi)</span>.<sup about="#mwt1059" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ocean23_2_112_200-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ocean23_2_112"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ocean23_2_112-200" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 188;" id="mwBYk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBYo">[188]</span></a></sup> If all of Earth's crustal surface were at the same elevation as a smooth sphere, the depth of the resulting world ocean would be <span about="#mwt1058" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2.7"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"2.8"},"4":{"wt":"km"},"5":{"wt":"mi"},"6":{"wt":"2"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYs">2.7 to 2.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1058">Â </span><span about="#mwt1058">km (1.68 to 1.74</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1058">Â </span><span about="#mwt1058">mi)</span>.<sup about="#mwt1063" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-201" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-201"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-201" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 189;" id="mwBYw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBY0">[189]</span></a></sup> About 97.5% of the water is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saline_water" title="Saline water" id="mwBY4">saline</a>; the remaining 2.5% is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fresh_water" title="Fresh water" id="mwBY8">fresh water</a>.<sup about="#mwt1067" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-202" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-202"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-202" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 190;" id="mwBZA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZE">[190]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1071" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-203" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-203"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-203" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 191;" id="mwBZI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZM">[191]</span></a></sup> Most fresh water, about 68.7%, is present as ice in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_cap" title="Ice cap" id="mwBZQ">ice caps</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Glacier" title="Glacier" id="mwBZU">glaciers</a>.<sup about="#mwt1075" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-204" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-204"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-204" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 192;" id="mwBZY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZc">[192]</span></a></sup> The remaining 30% is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ground_water" title="Ground water" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBZg">ground water</a>, 1% <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Surface_water" title="Surface water" id="mwBZk">surface water</a> (covering only 2.8% of Earth's land)<sup about="#mwt1079" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lake_Scientist_2016_205-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lake Scientist 2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lake_Scientist_2016-205"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Lake_Scientist_2016-205" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 193;" id="mwBZo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZs">[193]</span></a></sup> and other small forms of fresh water deposits such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permafrost" title="Permafrost" id="mwBZw">permafrost</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_vapor" title="Water vapor" id="mwBZ0">water vapor</a> in the atmosphere, biological binding, etc. .<sup about="#mwt1083" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-School_2019_206-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"School 2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-School_2019-206"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-School_2019-206" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 194;" id="mwBZ4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZ8">[194]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1087" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Education_2022_207-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Education 2022"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Education_2022-207"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Education_2022-207" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 195;" id="mwBaA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBaE">[195]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBaI">In Earth's coldest regions, snow survives over the summer and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_formation" title="Ice formation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBaM">changes into ice</a>. This accumulated snow and ice eventually forms into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Glacier" title="Glacier" id="mwBaQ">glaciers</a>, bodies of ice that flow under the influence of their own gravity. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alpine_glaciers" title="Alpine glaciers" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBaU">Alpine glaciers</a> form in mountainous areas, whereas vast <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_sheets" title="Ice sheets" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBaY">ice sheets</a> form over land in polar regions. The flow of glaciers erodes the surface changing it dramatically, with the formation of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./U-shaped_valley" title="U-shaped valley" id="mwBac">U-shaped valleys</a> and other landforms.<sup about="#mwt1093" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-208" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-208"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-208" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 196;" id="mwBag"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBak">[196]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_ice" title="Sea ice" id="mwBao">Sea ice</a> in the Arctic covers an area about as big as the United States, although it is quickly retreating as a consequence of climate change.<sup about="#mwt1097" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-209" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-209"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-209" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 197;" id="mwBas"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBaw">[197]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBa0">The average <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Salinity" title="Salinity" id="mwBa4">salinity</a> of Earth's oceans is about 35<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBa8">Â </span>grams of salt per kilogram of seawater (3.5% salt).<sup about="#mwt1103" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kennish2001_210-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kennish2001"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-kennish2001-210" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 198;" id="mwBbA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbE">[198]</span></a></sup> Most of this salt was released from volcanic activity or extracted from cool igneous rocks.<sup about="#mwt1104" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mullen2002_211-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mullen2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-mullen2002-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 199;" id="mwBbI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbM">[199]</span></a></sup> The oceans are also a reservoir of dissolved atmospheric gases, which are essential for the survival of many aquatic life forms.<sup about="#mwt1105" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-natsci_oxy4_212-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"natsci_oxy4"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-natsci_oxy4-212" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 200;" id="mwBbQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbU">[200]</span></a></sup> Sea water has an important influence on the world's climate, with the oceans acting as a large <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heat_reservoir" title="Heat reservoir" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbY">heat reservoir</a>.<sup about="#mwt1106" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-michon2006_213-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"michon2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-michon2006-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 201;" id="mwBbc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbg">[201]</span></a></sup> Shifts in the oceanic temperature distribution can cause significant weather shifts, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./El_NiÃ±oâ€“Southern_Oscillation" title="El NiÃ±oâ€“Southern Oscillation" id="mwBbk">El NiÃ±oâ€“Southern Oscillation</a>.<sup about="#mwt1107" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sample2005_214-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sample2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sample2005-214" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 202;" id="mwBbo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbs">[202]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBbw">The abundance of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water" title="Water" id="mwBb0">water</a>, particularly liquid water, on Earth's surface is a unique feature that distinguishes it from other planets in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_System" title="Solar System" id="mwBb4">Solar System</a>. Solar System planets with considerable atmospheres do partly host atmospheric water vapor, but they lack surface conditions for stable surface water.<sup about="#mwt1113" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Center_2021_215-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Center 2021"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Center_2021-215"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Center_2021-215" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 203;" id="mwBb8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBcA">[203]</span></a></sup> Despite some <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite" id="mwBcE">moons</a> showing signs of large reservoirs of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extraterrestrial_liquid_water" title="Extraterrestrial liquid water" id="mwBcI">extraterrestrial liquid water</a>, with possibly even more volume than Earth's ocean, all of them are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_largest_lakes_and_seas_in_the_Solar_System" title="List of largest lakes and seas in the Solar System" id="mwBcM">large bodies of water</a> under a kilometers thick frozen surface layer.<sup about="#mwt1117" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-216" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-216"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-216" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 204;" id="mwBcQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBcU">[204]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="24" id="mwBcY"><h2 id="Atmosphere">Atmosphere</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1118" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Atmosphere of Earth"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBcc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1118" id="mwBcg">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth">Atmosphere of Earth</a></div>
