<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBck"><a href="./File:ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBco"><img resource="./File:ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg/220px-ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3280" data-file-type="bitmap" height="146" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg/330px-ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg/440px-ISS-42_Waning_sun.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBcs"/></a><figcaption id="mwBcw">A view of Earth with different layers of its atmosphere visible: the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troposphere" title="Troposphere" id="mwBc0">troposphere</a> with its clouds casting shadows, a band of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stratospheric" title="Stratospheric" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBc4">stratospheric</a> blue sky at the horizon, and a line of green <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Airglow" title="Airglow" id="mwBc8">airglow</a> of the lower <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermosphere" title="Thermosphere" id="mwBdA">thermosphere</a> around an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./KÃ¡rmÃ¡n_line" title="KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line" id="mwBdE">altitude of 100<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBdI">Â </span>km, at the edge of space</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBdM">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmospheric_pressure" title="Atmospheric pressure" id="mwBdQ">atmospheric pressure</a> at Earth's sea level averages <span about="#mwt1128" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"101.325"},"2":{"wt":"kPa"},"3":{"wt":"psi"},"4":{"wt":"3"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBdU">101.325</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1128">Â </span><span about="#mwt1128">kPa (14.696</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1128">Â </span><span about="#mwt1128">psi)</span>,<sup about="#mwt1135" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Exline2006_217-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Exline2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Exline2006-217"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Exline2006-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwBdY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBdc">[205]</span></a></sup> with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scale_height" title="Scale height" id="mwBdg">scale height</a> of about <span about="#mwt1129" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"8.5"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBdk">8.5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1129">Â </span><span about="#mwt1129">km (5.3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1129">Â </span><span about="#mwt1129">mi)</span>.<sup about="#mwt1136" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-20" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"earth_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwBdo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBds">[3]</span></a></sup> A dry atmosphere is composed of 78.084% <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen" id="mwBdw">nitrogen</a>, 20.946% oxygen, 0.934% <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Argon" title="Argon" id="mwBd0">argon</a>, and trace amounts of carbon dioxide and other gaseous molecules.<sup about="#mwt1137" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Exline2006_217-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Exline2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Exline2006-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwBd4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBd8">[205]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_vapor" title="Water vapor" id="mwBeA">Water vapor</a> content varies between 0.01% and 4%<sup about="#mwt1138" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Exline2006_217-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Exline2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Exline2006-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwBeE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBeI">[205]</span></a></sup> but averages about 1%.<sup about="#mwt1139" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-21" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"earth_fact_sheet"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwBeM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBeQ">[3]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloud_cover" title="Cloud cover" id="mwBeU">Clouds cover</a> around two thirds of Earth's surface, more so over oceans than land.<sup about="#mwt1143" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-King_Platnick_Menzel_Ackerman_2013_pp._3826â€“3852_218-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"King Platnick Menzel Ackerman 2013 pp. 3826â€“3852"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-King_Platnick_Menzel_Ackerman_2013_pp._3826â€“3852-218"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-King_Platnick_Menzel_Ackerman_2013_pp._3826â€“3852-218" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 206;" id="mwBeY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBec">[206]</span></a></sup> The height of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troposphere" title="Troposphere" id="mwBeg">troposphere</a> varies with latitude, ranging between <span about="#mwt1130" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"8"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"4":{"wt":"0"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBek">8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1130">Â </span><span about="#mwt1130">km (5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1130">Â </span><span about="#mwt1130">mi)</span> at the poles to <span about="#mwt1131" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"17"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"4":{"wt":"0"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBeo">17</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1131">Â </span><span about="#mwt1131">km (11</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1131">Â </span><span about="#mwt1131">mi)</span> at the equator, with some variation resulting from weather and seasonal factors.<sup about="#mwt1144" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-geerts_linacre97_219-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"geerts_linacre97"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-geerts_linacre97-219" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 207;" id="mwBes"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBew">[207]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBe0">Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biosphere" title="Biosphere" id="mwBe4">biosphere</a> has significantly altered its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth" id="mwBe8">atmosphere</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxygen_evolution#Oxygen_evolution_in_nature" title="Oxygen evolution" id="mwBfA">Oxygenic photosynthesis</a> evolved <span class="nowrap" about="#mwt1150" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"val","href":"./Template:Val"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2.7"},"u":{"wt":"Gya"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBfE"><span data-sort-value="7000270000000000000â™ "></span>2.7<span typeof="mw:Entity">Â </span>Gya</span>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxygen_catastrophe" title="Oxygen catastrophe" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBfI">forming</a> the primarily nitrogenâ€“oxygen atmosphere of today.<sup about="#mwt1153" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20131003_67-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20131003"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-NYT-20131003-67" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwBfM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfQ">[63]</span></a></sup> This change enabled the proliferation of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerobic_organisms" title="Aerobic organisms" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBfU">aerobic organisms</a> and, indirectly, the formation of the ozone layer due to the subsequent <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ozoneâ€“oxygen_cycle" title="Ozoneâ€“oxygen cycle" id="mwBfY">conversion of atmospheric <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1123817410" about="#mwt1158" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"chem2","href":"./Template:Chem2"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"O2"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBfc"/><span class="chemf nowrap" about="#mwt1158" id="mwBfg">O<sub class="template-chem2-sub">2</sub></span> into <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1123817410" about="#mwt1161" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"chem2","href":"./Template:Chem2"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"O3"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBfk"/><span class="chemf nowrap" about="#mwt1161" id="mwBfo">O<sub class="template-chem2-sub">3</sub></span></a>. The ozone layer blocks <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet" id="mwBfs">ultraviolet</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_radiation" title="Solar radiation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBfw">solar radiation</a>, permitting life on land.<sup about="#mwt1154" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Harrison_2002_220-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Harrison 2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Harrison_2002-220" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 208;" id="mwBf0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBf4">[208]</span></a></sup> Other atmospheric functions important to life include transporting water vapor, providing useful gases, causing small meteors to burn up before they strike the surface, and moderating temperature.<sup about="#mwt1155" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-atmosphere_221-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"atmosphere"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-atmosphere-221" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 209;" id="mwBf8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBgA">[209]</span></a></sup> This last phenomenon is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenhouse_effect" title="Greenhouse effect" id="mwBgE">greenhouse effect</a>: trace molecules within the atmosphere serve to capture <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermal_energy" title="Thermal energy" id="mwBgI">thermal energy</a> emitted from the surface, thereby raising the average temperature. Water vapor, carbon dioxide, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Methane" title="Methane" id="mwBgM">methane</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nitrous_oxide" title="Nitrous oxide" id="mwBgQ">nitrous oxide</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ozone" title="Ozone" id="mwBgU">ozone</a> are the primary greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Without this heat-retention effect, the average surface temperature would be <span about="#mwt1151" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"âˆ’18"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBgY">âˆ’18</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1151">Â </span><span about="#mwt1151">Â°C (0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1151">Â </span><span about="#mwt1151">Â°F)</span>, in contrast to the current <span about="#mwt1152" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"+15"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBgc">+15</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1152">Â </span><span about="#mwt1152">Â°C (59</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1152">Â </span><span about="#mwt1152">Â°F)</span>,<sup about="#mwt1156" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Pidwirny2006_7_222-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Pidwirny2006_7"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Pidwirny2006_7-222" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 210;" id="mwBgg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBgk">[210]</span></a></sup> and life on Earth probably would not exist in its current form.<sup about="#mwt1157" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Narottam2008_223-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Narottam2008"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Narottam2008-223" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwBgo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBgs">[211]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="25" id="mwBgw"><h3 id="Weather_and_climate">Weather and climate</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1164" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Weather"},"2":{"wt":"Climate"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBg0"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1164" id="mwBg4">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weather" title="Weather">Weather</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Climate" title="Climate">Climate</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1167" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Multiple image\n","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"right"},"direction":{"wt":"vertical"},"width":{"wt":"300"},"image1":{"wt":"IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg"},"caption1":{"wt":"The [[ITCZ]]&apos;s band of clouds over the [[Eastern Pacific]] and the [[Americas]] as seen from space"},"image5":{"wt":"KÃ¶ppen-Geiger Climate Classification Map (1980â€“2016) no borders.png"},"caption5":{"wt":"Worldwide [[KÃ¶ppen climate classification]]s"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBg8">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright" about="#mwt1167" id="mwBhA"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:304px;max-width:304px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:302px;max-width:302px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg/300px-IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2772" data-file-height="1250" data-file-type="bitmap" height="135" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg/450px-IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg/600px-IntertropicalConvergenceZone-EO.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./ITCZ" title="ITCZ" class="mw-redirect">ITCZ</a>'s band of clouds over the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eastern_Pacific" title="Eastern Pacific" class="mw-redirect">Eastern Pacific</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> as seen from space</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:302px;max-width:302px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:KÃ¶ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_(1980â€“2016)_no_borders.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:KÃ¶ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_(1980â€“2016)_no_borders.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png/300px-K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="2160" data-file-type="bitmap" height="150" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png/450px-K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png/600px-K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger_Climate_Classification_Map_%281980%E2%80%932016%29_no_borders.png 2x" class="mw-file-element"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Worldwide <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./KÃ¶ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classifications</a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p id="mwBhE">Earth's atmosphere has no definite boundary, gradually becoming thinner and fading into outer space.<sup about="#mwt1177" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-224" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-224"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-224" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwBhI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhM">[212]</span></a></sup> Three-quarters of the atmosphere's mass is contained within the first <span about="#mwt1173" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"11"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBhQ">11</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1173">Â </span><span about="#mwt1173">km (6.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1173">Â </span><span about="#mwt1173">mi)</span> of the surface; this lowest layer is called the troposphere.<sup about="#mwt1181" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-225" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-225"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-225" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;" id="mwBhU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhY">[213]</span></a></sup> Energy from the Sun heats this layer, and the surface below, causing expansion of the air. This lower-density air then rises and is replaced by cooler, higher-density air. The result is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmospheric_circulation" title="Atmospheric circulation" id="mwBhc">atmospheric circulation</a> that drives the weather and climate through redistribution of thermal energy.<sup about="#mwt1182" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-moran2005_226-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"moran2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-moran2005-226" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;" id="mwBhg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhk">[214]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBho">The primary atmospheric circulation bands consist of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trade_winds" title="Trade winds" id="mwBhs">trade winds</a> in the equatorial region below 30Â° latitude and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Westerlies" title="Westerlies" id="mwBhw">westerlies</a> in the mid-latitudes between 30Â° and 60Â°.<sup about="#mwt1185" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-berger2002_227-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"berger2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-berger2002-227" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;" id="mwBh0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBh4">[215]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_heat_content" title="Ocean heat content" id="mwBh8">Ocean heat content</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_current" title="Ocean current" id="mwBiA">currents</a> are also important factors in determining climate, particularly the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermohaline_circulation" title="Thermohaline circulation" id="mwBiE">thermohaline circulation</a> that distributes thermal energy from the equatorial oceans to the polar regions.<sup about="#mwt1186" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-rahmstorf2003_228-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"rahmstorf2003"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-rahmstorf2003-228" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 216;" id="mwBiI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBiM">[216]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBiQ">Earth receives 1361<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBiU">Â </span>W/m<sup id="mwBiY">2</sup> of<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBic">Â </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solar_irradiance" title="Solar irradiance" id="mwBig">solar irradiance</a>.<sup about="#mwt1195" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-229" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-229"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-229" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 217;" id="mwBik"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBio">[217]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1199" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-230" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-230"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-230" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 218;" id="mwBis"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBiw">[218]</span></a></sup> The amount of solar energy that reaches Earth's surface decreases with increasing latitude. At higher latitudes, the sunlight reaches the surface at lower angles, and it must pass through thicker columns of the atmosphere. As a result, the mean annual air temperature at sea level decreases by about <span about="#mwt1191" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"0.4"},"2":{"wt":"C-change"},"3":{"wt":"F-change"},"4":{"wt":"1"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBi0">0.4</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1191">Â </span><span about="#mwt1191">Â°C (0.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1191">Â </span><span about="#mwt1191">Â°F)</span> per degree of latitude from the equator.<sup about="#mwt1200" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sadava_heller2006_231-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sadava_heller2006"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sadava_heller2006-231" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 219;" id="mwBi4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBi8">[219]</span></a></sup> Earth's surface can be subdivided into specific latitudinal belts of approximately homogeneous climate. Ranging from the equator to the polar regions, these are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropics" title="Tropics" id="mwBjA">tropical</a> (or equatorial), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Subtropics" title="Subtropics" id="mwBjE">subtropical</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Temperate" title="Temperate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjI">temperate</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_region" title="Polar region" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjM">polar</a> climates.<sup about="#mwt1201" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-climate_zones_232-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"climate_zones"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-climate_zones-232" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 220;" id="mwBjQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjU">[220]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBjY">Further factors that affect a location's climates are its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continentality" title="Continentality" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjc">proximity to oceans</a>, the oceanic and atmospheric circulation, and topology.<sup about="#mwt1209" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-233" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-233"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-233" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 221;" id="mwBjg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjk">[221]</span></a></sup> Places close to oceans typically have colder summers and warmer winters, due to the fact that oceans can store large amounts of heat. The wind transports the cold or the heat of the ocean to the land.<sup about="#mwt1213" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-234" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-234"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-234" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 222;" id="mwBjo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjs">[222]</span></a></sup> Atmospheric circulation also plays an important role: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./San_Francisco" title="San Francisco" id="mwBjw">San Francisco</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Washington_DC" title="Washington DC" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBj0">Washington DC</a> are both coastal cities at about the same latitude. San Francisco's climate is significantly more moderate as the prevailing wind direction is from sea to land.<sup about="#mwt1217" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-235" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-235"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-235" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 223;" id="mwBj4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBj8">[223]</span></a></sup> Finally, temperatures <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lapse_rate" title="Lapse rate" id="mwBkA">decrease with height</a> causing mountainous areas to be colder than low-lying areas.<sup about="#mwt1221" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-236" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-236"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-236" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 224;" id="mwBkE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkI">[224]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBkM">Water vapor generated through surface evaporation is transported by circulatory patterns in the atmosphere. When atmospheric conditions permit an uplift of warm, humid air, this water condenses and falls to the surface as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Precipitation" title="Precipitation" id="mwBkQ">precipitation</a>.<sup about="#mwt1224" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-moran2005_226-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"moran2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-moran2005-226" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;" id="mwBkU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkY">[214]</span></a></sup> Most of the water is then transported to lower elevations by river systems and usually returned to the oceans or deposited into lakes. This <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_cycle" title="Water cycle" id="mwBkc">water cycle</a> is a vital mechanism for supporting life on land and is a primary factor in the erosion of surface features over geological periods. Precipitation patterns vary widely, ranging from several meters of water per year to less than a millimeter. Atmospheric circulation, topographic features, and temperature differences determine the average precipitation that falls in each region.<sup about="#mwt1225" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hydrologic_cycle_237-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hydrologic_cycle"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-hydrologic_cycle-237" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 225;" id="mwBkg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkk">[225]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBko">The commonly used <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./KÃ¶ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification" id="mwBks">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a> system has five broad groups (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate" id="mwBkw">humid tropics</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arid" title="Arid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBk0">arid</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate" id="mwBk4">humid middle latitudes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Continental_climate" title="Continental climate" id="mwBk8">continental</a> and cold <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_climate" title="Polar climate" id="mwBlA">polar</a>), which are further divided into more specific subtypes.<sup about="#mwt1232" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-berger2002_227-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"berger2002"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-berger2002-227" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;" id="mwBlE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBlI">[215]</span></a></sup> The KÃ¶ppen system rates regions based on observed temperature and precipitation.<sup about="#mwt1236" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-238" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-238"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-238" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 226;" id="mwBlM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBlQ">[226]</span></a></sup> Surface <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Highest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth" title="Highest temperature recorded on Earth" id="mwBlU">air temperature can rise to</a> around <span about="#mwt1230" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"55"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlY">55</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1230">Â </span><span about="#mwt1230">Â°C (131</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1230">Â </span><span about="#mwt1230">Â°F)</span> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hot_desert" title="Hot desert" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBlc">hot deserts</a>, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Death_Valley_National_Park" title="Death Valley National Park" id="mwBlg">Death Valley</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lowest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth" title="Lowest temperature recorded on Earth" id="mwBlk">can fall as low as</a> <span about="#mwt1231" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"-89"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlo">âˆ’89</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1231">Â </span><span about="#mwt1231">Â°C (âˆ’128</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1231">Â </span><span about="#mwt1231">Â°F)</span> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwBls">Antarctica</a>.<sup about="#mwt1240" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-239" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-239"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-239" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 227;" id="mwBlw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBl0">[227]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1244" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-240" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-240"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-240" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 228;" id="mwBl4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBl8">[228]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="26" id="mwBmA"><h3 id="Upper_atmosphere">Upper atmosphere</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBmE"><a href="./File:Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBmI"><img resource="./File:Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg/280px-Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4285" data-file-height="2273" data-file-type="bitmap" height="149" width="280" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg/420px-Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg/560px-Antarctic_aurora_ESA313457.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBmM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBmQ">Earth's atmosphere as it appears from space, as bands of different colours at the horizon. From the bottom, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Afterglow" title="Afterglow" id="mwBmU">afterglow</a> illuminates the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troposphere" title="Troposphere" id="mwBmY">troposphere</a> in orange with silhouettes of clouds, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stratosphere" title="Stratosphere" id="mwBmc">stratosphere</a> in white and blue. Next the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesosphere" title="Mesosphere" id="mwBmg">mesosphere</a> (pink area) extends to just below the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./KÃ¡rmÃ¡n_line" title="KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line" id="mwBmk">edge of space</a> at one hundred kilometers and the pink line of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Airglow" title="Airglow" id="mwBmo">airglow</a> of the lower <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermosphere" title="Thermosphere" id="mwBms">thermosphere</a> (invisible), which hosts green and red <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aurora" title="Aurora" id="mwBmw">aurorae</a> over several hundred kilometers.</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBm0">The upper atmosphere, the atmosphere above the troposphere,<sup about="#mwt1253" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-241" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-241"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-241" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;" id="mwBm4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBm8">[229]</span></a></sup> is usually divided into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stratosphere" title="Stratosphere" id="mwBnA">stratosphere</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesosphere" title="Mesosphere" id="mwBnE">mesosphere</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermosphere" title="Thermosphere" id="mwBnI">thermosphere</a>.<sup about="#mwt1254" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-atmosphere_221-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"atmosphere"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-atmosphere-221" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 209;" id="mwBnM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBnQ">[209]</span></a></sup> Each layer has a different lapse rate, defining the rate of change in temperature with height. Beyond these, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Exosphere" title="Exosphere" id="mwBnU">exosphere</a> thins out into the magnetosphere, where the geomagnetic fields interact with the solar wind.<sup about="#mwt1255" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sciweek2004_242-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sciweek2004"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sciweek2004-242" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 230;" id="mwBnY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBnc">[230]</span></a></sup> Within the stratosphere is the ozone layer, a component that partially shields the surface from ultraviolet light and thus is important for life on Earth. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./KÃ¡rmÃ¡n_line" title="KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line" id="mwBng">KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line</a>, defined as <span about="#mwt1249" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBnk">100</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1249">Â </span><span about="#mwt1249">km (62</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1249">Â </span><span about="#mwt1249">mi)</span> above Earth's surface, is a working definition for the boundary between the atmosphere and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Outer_space" title="Outer space" id="mwBno">outer space</a>.<sup about="#mwt1256" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cordoba2004_243-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cordoba2004"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-cordoba2004-243" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 231;" id="mwBns"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBnw">[231]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBn0">Thermal energy causes some of the molecules at the outer edge of the atmosphere to increase their velocity to the point where they can escape from Earth's gravity. This causes a slow but steady <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atmospheric_escape" title="Atmospheric escape" id="mwBn4">loss of the atmosphere into space</a>. Because unfixed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen" id="mwBn8">hydrogen</a> has a low <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molecular_mass" title="Molecular mass" id="mwBoA">molecular mass</a>, it can achieve <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Escape_velocity" title="Escape velocity" id="mwBoE">escape velocity</a> more readily, and it leaks into outer space at a greater rate than other gases.<sup about="#mwt1261" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jas31_4_1118_244-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jas31_4_1118"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-jas31_4_1118-244" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 232;" id="mwBoI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoM">[232]</span></a></sup> The leakage of hydrogen into space contributes to the shifting of Earth's atmosphere and surface from an initially <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Redox" title="Redox" id="mwBoQ">reducing</a> state to its current oxidizing one. Photosynthesis provided a source of free oxygen, but the loss of reducing agents such as hydrogen is thought to have been a necessary precondition for the widespread accumulation of oxygen in the atmosphere.<sup about="#mwt1262" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sci293_5531_839_245-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sci293_5531_839"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-sci293_5531_839-245" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 233;" id="mwBoU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoY">[233]</span></a></sup> Hence the ability of hydrogen to escape from the atmosphere may have influenced the nature of life that developed on Earth.<sup about="#mwt1263" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-abedon1997_246-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"abedon1997"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-abedon1997-246" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 234;" id="mwBoc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBog">[234]</span></a></sup> In the current, oxygen-rich atmosphere most hydrogen is converted into water before it has an opportunity to escape. Instead, most of the hydrogen loss comes from the destruction of methane in the upper atmosphere.<sup about="#mwt1264" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-arwps4_265_247-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"arwps4_265"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-arwps4_265-247" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 235;" id="mwBok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoo">[235]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="27" id="mwBos"><h2 id="Life_on_Earth">Life on Earth</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1265" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Biosphere"},"2":{"wt":"History of life"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBow"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1265" id="mwBo0">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biosphere" title="Biosphere">Biosphere</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_life" title="History of life">History of life</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBo4"><a href="./File:Mollweide_Cycle.gif" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBo8"><img resource="./File:Mollweide_Cycle.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Mollweide_Cycle.gif/330px-Mollweide_Cycle.gif" decoding="async" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="360" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="330" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Mollweide_Cycle.gif/495px-Mollweide_Cycle.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Mollweide_Cycle.gif/660px-Mollweide_Cycle.gif 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBpA"/></a><figcaption id="mwBpE">An animation of the changing density of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primary_production" title="Primary production" id="mwBpI">productive</a> vegetation on land (low in brown; heavy in dark green) and phytoplankton at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_surface" title="Ocean surface" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBpM">ocean surface</a> (low in purple; high in yellow)</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBpQ">Earth is the only known place that has ever been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_habitability" title="Planetary habitability" id="mwBpU">habitable</a> for life. Earth's life developed in Earth's early bodies of water some hundred million years after Earth formed.</p>

<p id="mwBpY">Earth's life has been shaping and inhabiting many particular <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem" id="mwBpc">ecosystems</a> on Earth and has eventually expanded globally forming an overarching biosphere.<sup about="#mwt1272" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-248" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-248"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-248" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 236;" id="mwBpg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBpk">[236]</span></a></sup> Therefore, life has impacted Earth, significantly altering Earth's atmosphere and surface over long periods of time, causing changes like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Great_Oxidation_Event" title="Great Oxidation Event" id="mwBpo">Great Oxidation Event</a>.</p>

<p id="mwBps">Earth's life has over time greatly diversified, allowing the biosphere to have different <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biome" title="Biome" id="mwBpw">biomes</a>, which are inhabited by comparatively similar plants and animals.<sup about="#mwt1278" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-249" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-249"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-249" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 237;" id="mwBp0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBp4">[237]</span></a></sup> The different biomes developed at distinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elevation" title="Elevation" id="mwBp8">elevations</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_depths" title="Ocean depths" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBqA">water depths</a>, planetary temperature <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latitude" title="Latitude" id="mwBqE">latitudes</a> and on land also with different <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Humidity" title="Humidity" id="mwBqI">humidity</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latitudinal_gradients_in_species_diversity" title="Latitudinal gradients in species diversity" id="mwBqM">Earth's species diversity</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)" id="mwBqQ">biomass</a> reaches a peak in shallow waters and with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest" id="mwBqU">forests, particularly in equatorial, warm and humid conditions</a>. While freezing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_regions_of_Earth" title="Polar regions of Earth" id="mwBqY">polar regions</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra" id="mwBqc">high altitudes</a>, or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Desert" title="Desert" id="mwBqg">extremely arid areas</a> are relatively barren of plant and animal life.<sup about="#mwt1279" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-amnat163_2_192_250-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"amnat163_2_192"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-amnat163_2_192-250" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 238;" id="mwBqk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBqo">[238]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBqs">Earth provides liquid waterâ€”an environment where complex <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Organic_compound" title="Organic compound" id="mwBqw">organic molecules</a> can assemble and interact, and sufficient energy to sustain a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metabolism" title="Metabolism" id="mwBq0">metabolism</a>.<sup about="#mwt1282" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ab2003_251-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ab2003"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ab2003-251" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 239;" id="mwBq4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBq8">[239]</span></a></sup> Plants and other organisms take up <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nutrient" title="Nutrient" id="mwBrA">nutrients</a> from water, soils and the atmosphere. These nutrients are constantly recycled between different species.<sup about="#mwt1286" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-252" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-252"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-252" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 240;" id="mwBrE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBrI">[240]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBrM">Extreme weather, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone" id="mwBrQ">tropical cyclones</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hurricane" title="Hurricane" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBrU">hurricanes</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Typhoon" title="Typhoon" id="mwBrY">typhoons</a>), occurs over most of Earth's surface and has a large impact on life in those areas. From 1980 to 2000, these events caused an average of 11,800 human deaths per year.<sup about="#mwt1295" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-253" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-253"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-253" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 241;" id="mwBrc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBrg">[241]</span></a></sup> Many places are subject to earthquakes, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Landslide" title="Landslide" id="mwBrk">landslides</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tsunami" title="Tsunami" id="mwBro">tsunamis</a>, volcanic eruptions, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tornado" title="Tornado" id="mwBrs">tornadoes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blizzard" title="Blizzard" id="mwBrw">blizzards</a>, floods, droughts, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wildfire" title="Wildfire" id="mwBr0">wildfires</a>, and other calamities and disasters.<sup about="#mwt1299" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-254" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-254"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-254" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 242;" id="mwBr4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBr8">[242]</span></a></sup> Human impact is felt in many areas due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pollution" title="Pollution" id="mwBsA">pollution</a> of the air and water, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acid_rain" title="Acid rain" id="mwBsE">acid rain</a>, loss of vegetation (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Overgrazing" title="Overgrazing" id="mwBsI">overgrazing</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deforestation" title="Deforestation" id="mwBsM">deforestation</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Desertification" title="Desertification" id="mwBsQ">desertification</a>), loss of wildlife, species <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction" title="Extinction" id="mwBsU">extinction</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soil_degradation" title="Soil degradation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBsY">soil degradation</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soil_depletion" title="Soil depletion" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBsc">soil depletion</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erosion" title="Erosion" id="mwBsg">erosion</a>.<sup about="#mwt1303" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-255" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-255"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-255" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 243;" id="mwBsk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBso">[243]</span></a></sup> Human activities release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere which cause <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Global_warming" title="Global warming" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBss">global warming</a>.<sup about="#mwt1307" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ConsensusOnConsensus_256-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ConsensusOnConsensus"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ConsensusOnConsensus-256"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ConsensusOnConsensus-256" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 244;" id="mwBsw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBs0">[244]</span></a></sup> This is driving <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Effects_of_climate_change" title="Effects of climate change" id="mwBs4">changes</a> such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retreat_of_glaciers_since_1850" title="Retreat of glaciers since 1850" id="mwBs8">melting of glaciers and ice sheets</a>, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise" id="mwBtA">global rise in average sea levels</a>, increased risk of drought and wildfires, and migration of species to colder areas.<sup about="#mwt1311" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Warming_Effects_257-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Global Warming Effects"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Global_Warming_Effects-257"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Global_Warming_Effects-257" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 245;" id="mwBtE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBtI">[245]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="28" id="mwBtM"><h2 id="Human_geography">Human geography</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1312" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Human geography"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBtQ"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1312" id="mwBtU">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_geography" title="Human geography">Human geography</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1315" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"World"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBtY"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1315" id="mwBtc">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./World" title="World">World</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBtg"><a href="./File:Earth's_City_Lights_by_DMSP,_1994-1995_(large).jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBtk"><img resource="./File:Earth's_City_Lights_by_DMSP,_1994-1995_(large).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg/300px-Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4800" data-file-height="2400" data-file-type="bitmap" height="150" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg/450px-Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg/600px-Earth%27s_City_Lights_by_DMSP%2C_1994-1995_%28large%29.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBto"/></a><figcaption id="mwBts">A composite image of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Light_pollution" title="Light pollution" id="mwBtw">artificial light emissions</a> at night on a map of Earth</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBt0">Originating from earlier <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primate" title="Primate" id="mwBt4">primates</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eastern_Africa" title="Eastern Africa" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBt8">eastern Africa</a> 300,000 years ago <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_human_migration" title="History of human migration" id="mwBuA">humans have since been migrating</a> and with the advent of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agriculture" title="Agriculture" id="mwBuE">agriculture</a> in the 10th millennium BC increasingly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sedentism" title="Sedentism" id="mwBuI">settling</a> Earth's land. In the 20th century <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwBuM">Antarctica</a> had been the last continent to see a first and until today limited human presence.</p>

<p id="mwBuQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./World_population" title="World population" id="mwBuU">Human population</a> has since the 19th century grown exponentially to seven billion in the early 2010s,<sup about="#mwt1324" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-258" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-258"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-258" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 246;" id="mwBuY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuc">[246]</span></a></sup> and is projected to peak at around ten billion in the second half of the 21st century.<sup about="#mwt1328" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Harvey-2020_259-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Harvey-2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Harvey-2020-259"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Harvey-2020-259" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 247;" id="mwBug"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuk">[247]</span></a></sup> Most of the growth is expected to take place in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa" id="mwBuo">sub-Saharan Africa</a>.<sup about="#mwt1329" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Harvey-2020_259-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Harvey-2020"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Harvey-2020-259" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 247;" id="mwBus"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuw">[247]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBu0">Distribution and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Population_density#Human_population_density" title="Population density" id="mwBu4">density of human population</a> varies greatly around the world with the majority living in south to eastern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Asia" title="Asia" id="mwBu8">Asia</a> and 90% inhabiting only the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere" id="mwBvA">Northern Hemisphere</a> of Earth,<sup about="#mwt1336" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-260" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-260"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-260" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 248;" id="mwBvE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvI">[248]</span></a></sup> partly due to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land_hemisphere" title="Land hemisphere" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBvM">hemispherical predominance of the world's land mass</a>, with 68% of the world's land mass being in the Northern Hemisphere.<sup about="#mwt1340" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-261" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-261"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-261" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 249;" id="mwBvQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvU">[249]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, since the 19th century humans have increasingly converged into urban areas with the majority living in urban areas by the 21st century.<sup about="#mwt1341" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OWID_urbanization_2019_262-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OWID_urbanization_2019"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-OWID_urbanization_2019-262" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 250;" id="mwBvY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvc">[250]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBvg">Beyond Earth's surface humans have lived on a temporary basis, with only special purpose deep <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Underground_living" title="Underground living" id="mwBvk">underground</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Underwater_living" title="Underwater living" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBvo">underwater</a> presence, and a few <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Space_station" title="Space station" id="mwBvs">space stations</a>. Human population virtually completely remains on Earth's surface, fully depending on Earth and the environment it sustains. Since the second half of the 20th century, some hundreds of humans have temporarily stayed beyond Earth, a tiny fraction of whom have reached another celestial body, the Moon.<sup about="#mwt1344" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-shayler_vis2005_263-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"shayler_vis2005"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-shayler_vis2005-263" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 251;" id="mwBvw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBv0">[251]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1348" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-264" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-264"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-264" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 252;" id="mwBv4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBv8">[252]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBwA">Earth has been subject to extensive human settlement, and humans have developed diverse <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Society" title="Society" id="mwBwE">societies</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Culture" title="Culture" id="mwBwI">cultures</a>. Most of Earth's land has been territorially claimed since the 19th century by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state" id="mwBwM">sovereign states</a> (countries) separated by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Border" title="Border" id="mwBwQ">political borders</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states" id="mwBwU">more than 200 such states</a> exist today,<sup about="#mwt1355" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-265" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-265"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-265" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 253;" id="mwBwY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBwc">[253]</span></a></sup> with only parts of Antarctica and few small regions <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terra_nullius" title="Terra nullius" id="mwBwg">remaining unclaimed</a>.<sup about="#mwt1359" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-266" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-266"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 254;" id="mwBwk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBwo">[254]</span></a></sup> Most of these states together form the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./United_Nations" title="United Nations" id="mwBws">United Nations</a>, the leading worldwide <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intergovernmental_organization" title="Intergovernmental organization" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBww">intergovernmental organization</a>,<sup about="#mwt1363" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-267" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-267"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-267" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 255;" id="mwBw0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBw4">[255]</span></a></sup> which extends human governance <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Law_of_the_Sea" title="Law of the Sea" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBw8">over the ocean</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctic_Treaty_System" title="Antarctic Treaty System" id="mwBxA">Antarctica</a>, and therefore all of Earth.</p>

<section data-mw-section-id="29" id="mwBxE"><h3 id="Natural_resources_and_land_use">Natural resources and land use</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1364" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Natural resource"},"2":{"wt":"Land use"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBxI"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1364" id="mwBxM">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">Natural resource</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Land_use" title="Land use">Land use</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBxQ"><a href="./File:Global-land-use-graphic.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBxU"><img resource="./File:Global-land-use-graphic.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Global-land-use-graphic.png/300px-Global-land-use-graphic.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="6251" data-file-height="3951" data-file-type="bitmap" height="190" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Global-land-use-graphic.png/450px-Global-land-use-graphic.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Global-land-use-graphic.png/600px-Global-land-use-graphic.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwBxY"/></a><figcaption id="mwBxc">Earth's land use for human agriculture</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBxg">Earth has resources that have been exploited by humans.<sup about="#mwt1376" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-268" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-268"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-268" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 256;" id="mwBxk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxo">[256]</span></a></sup> Those termed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Non-renewable_resource" title="Non-renewable resource" id="mwBxs">non-renewable resources</a>, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel" id="mwBxw">fossil fuels</a>, are only replenished over geological timescales.<sup about="#mwt1380" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-269" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-269"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-269" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 257;" id="mwBx0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBx4">[257]</span></a></sup> Large deposits of fossil fuels are obtained from Earth's crust, consisting of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coal" title="Coal" id="mwBx8">coal</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Petroleum" title="Petroleum" id="mwByA">petroleum</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_gas" title="Natural gas" id="mwByE">natural gas</a>.<sup about="#mwt1384" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-270" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-270"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-270" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 258;" id="mwByI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByM">[258]</span></a></sup> These deposits are used by humans both for energy production and as feedstock for chemical production.<sup about="#mwt1388" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-271" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-271"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-271" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 259;" id="mwByQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByU">[259]</span></a></sup> Mineral <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ore" title="Ore" id="mwByY">ore</a> bodies have also been formed within the crust through a process of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ore_genesis" title="Ore genesis" id="mwByc">ore genesis</a>, resulting from actions of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magmatism" title="Magmatism" id="mwByg">magmatism</a>, erosion, and plate tectonics.<sup about="#mwt1392" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-272" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-272"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-272" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 260;" id="mwByk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByo">[260]</span></a></sup> These <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metal" title="Metal" id="mwBys">metals</a> and other elements are extracted by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mining" title="Mining" id="mwByw">mining</a>, a process which often brings environmental and health damage.<sup about="#mwt1396" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-273" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-273"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-273" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 261;" id="mwBy0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBy4">[261]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBy8">Earth's biosphere produces many useful biological products for humans, including food, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wood" title="Wood" id="mwBzA">wood</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pharmaceutical" title="Pharmaceutical" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBzE">pharmaceuticals</a>, oxygen, and the recycling of organic waste. The land-based ecosystem depends upon <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Topsoil" title="Topsoil" id="mwBzI">topsoil</a> and fresh water, and the oceanic ecosystem depends on dissolved nutrients washed down from the land.<sup about="#mwt1406" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-science299_5607_673_274-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"science299_5607_673"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-science299_5607_673-274" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 262;" id="mwBzM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzQ">[262]</span></a></sup> In 2019, <span about="#mwt1401" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"39"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBzU">39</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1401">Â </span><span about="#mwt1401">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1401">Â </span><span about="#mwt1401">km</span><sup about="#mwt1401">2</sup><span about="#mwt1401"> (15</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1401">Â </span><span about="#mwt1401">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1401">Â </span><span about="#mwt1401">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1401">Â </span><span about="#mwt1401">mi)</span> of Earth's land surface consisted of forest and woodlands, <span about="#mwt1402" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"12"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBzY">12</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1402">Â </span><span about="#mwt1402">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1402">Â </span><span about="#mwt1402">km</span><sup about="#mwt1402">2</sup><span about="#mwt1402"> (4.6</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1402">Â </span><span about="#mwt1402">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1402">Â </span><span about="#mwt1402">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1402">Â </span><span about="#mwt1402">mi)</span> was shrub and grassland, <span about="#mwt1403" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"40"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBzc">40</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1403">Â </span><span about="#mwt1403">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1403">Â </span><span about="#mwt1403">km</span><sup about="#mwt1403">2</sup><span about="#mwt1403"> (15</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1403">Â </span><span about="#mwt1403">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1403">Â </span><span about="#mwt1403">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1403">Â </span><span about="#mwt1403">mi)</span> were used for animal feed production and grazing, and <span about="#mwt1404" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"11"},"2":{"wt":"e6km2"},"3":{"wt":"e6sqmi"},"abbr":{"wt":"unit"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBzg">11</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1404">Â </span><span about="#mwt1404">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1404">Â </span><span about="#mwt1404">km</span><sup about="#mwt1404">2</sup><span about="#mwt1404"> (4.2</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1404">Â </span><span about="#mwt1404">million</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1404">Â </span><span about="#mwt1404">sq</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1404">Â </span><span about="#mwt1404">mi)</span> were cultivated as croplands.<sup about="#mwt1407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OWID_2019_275-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OWID_2019"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-OWID_2019-275" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 263;" id="mwBzk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzo">[263]</span></a></sup> Of the 12<span about="#mwt1405" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"En dash","href":"./Template:En_dash"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBzs">â€“</span>14% of ice-free land that is used for croplands, 2 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Percentage_point" title="Percentage point" id="mwBzw">percentage points</a> were irrigated in 2015.<sup about="#mwt1411" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-276" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-276"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-276" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 264;" id="mwBz0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBz4">[264]</span></a></sup> Humans use <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Building_material" title="Building material" id="mwBz8">building materials</a> to construct shelters.<sup about="#mwt1415" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-277" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-277"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-277" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwB0A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0E">[265]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="30" id="mwB0I"><h3 id="Humans_and_the_environment">Humans and the environment</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1416" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Human impact on the environment"},"2":{"wt":"Climate change"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB0M"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1416" id="mwB0Q">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">Human impact on the environment</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Climate_change" title="Climate change">Climate change</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB0U"><a href="./File:Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB0Y"><img alt="The graph from 1880 to 2020 shows natural drivers exhibiting fluctuations of about 0.3 degrees Celsius. Human drivers steadily increase by 0.3 degrees over 100 years to 1980, then steeply by 0.8 degrees more over the past 40 years." resource="./File:Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg/260px-Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="720" data-file-type="drawing" height="195" width="260" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg/390px-Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg/520px-Global_Temperature_And_Forces_With_Fahrenheit.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwB0c"/></a><figcaption id="mwB0g">Change in average surface air temperature and drivers for that change. Human activity has caused increased temperatures, with natural forces adding some variability.<sup about="#mwt1423" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-278" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-278"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-278" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 266;" id="mwB0k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0o">[266]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwB0s">Human activities have impacted Earth's environments. Through activities such as the burning of fossil fuels, humans have been increasing the amount of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas" id="mwB0w">greenhouse gases</a> in the atmosphere, altering <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_energy_budget" title="Earth's energy budget" id="mwB00">Earth's energy budget</a> and climate.<sup about="#mwt1429" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ConsensusOnConsensus_256-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ConsensusOnConsensus"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-ConsensusOnConsensus-256" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 244;" id="mwB04"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB08">[244]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1433" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-279" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-279"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-279" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 267;" id="mwB1A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB1E">[267]</span></a></sup> It is estimated that global temperatures in the year 2020 were <span about="#mwt1428" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.2"},"2":{"wt":"C-change"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB1I">1.2</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1428">Â </span><span about="#mwt1428">Â°C (2.2</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1428">Â </span><span about="#mwt1428">Â°F)</span> warmer than the preindustrial baseline.<sup about="#mwt1437" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-280" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-280"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-280" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 268;" id="mwB1M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB1Q">[268]</span></a></sup> This increase in temperature, known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Global_warming" title="Global warming" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB1U">global warming</a>, has contributed to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retreat_of_glaciers_since_1850" title="Retreat of glaciers since 1850" id="mwB1Y">melting of glaciers</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise" id="mwB1c">rising sea levels</a>, increased risk of drought and wildfires, and migration of species to colder areas.<sup about="#mwt1438" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Warming_Effects_257-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Global Warming Effects"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Global_Warming_Effects-257" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 245;" id="mwB1g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB1k">[245]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB1o">The concept of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planetary_boundaries" title="Planetary boundaries" id="mwB1s">planetary boundaries</a> was introduced to quantify humanity's impact on Earth. Of the nine identified boundaries, five have been crossed: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biodiversity_loss" title="Biodiversity loss" id="mwB1w">Biosphere integrity</a>, climate change, chemical pollution, destruction of wild habitats and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nitrogen_cycle" title="Nitrogen cycle" id="mwB10">nitrogen cycle</a> are thought to have passed the safe threshold.<sup about="#mwt1445" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Boundaries_281-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Boundaries"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Boundaries-281"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Boundaries-281" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 269;" id="mwB14"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB18">[269]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1449" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-282" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-282"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-282" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 270;" id="mwB2A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2E">[270]</span></a></sup> As of 2018, no country meets the basic needs of its population without transgressing planetary boundaries. It is thought possible to provide all basic physical needs globally within sustainable levels of resource use.<sup about="#mwt1453" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-283" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-283"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-283" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 271;" id="mwB2I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2M">[271]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="31" id="mwB2Q"><h2 id="Cultural_and_historical_viewpoint">Cultural and historical viewpoint</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1454" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Earth in culture"},"2":{"wt":"Earth symbol"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB2U"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1454" id="mwB2Y">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_in_culture" title="Earth in culture">Earth in culture</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_symbol" title="Earth symbol">Earth symbol</a></div>
