<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB2c"><a href="./File:Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB2g"><img alt="Woman seeing the Earth from space through a window" resource="./File:Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg/220px-Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" data-file-type="bitmap" height="146" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg/330px-Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg/440px-Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson_in_Cupola_ISS.jpg 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwB2k"/></a><figcaption id="mwB2o"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tracy_Caldwell_Dyson" title="Tracy Caldwell Dyson" id="mwB2s">Tracy Caldwell Dyson</a>, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./NASA" title="NASA" id="mwB2w">NASA</a> astronaut, observing Earth from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cupola_(ISS_module)" title="Cupola (ISS module)" id="mwB20"><i id="mwB24">Cupola</i> module</a> at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station" id="mwB28">International Space Station</a> on 11 September 2010</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwB3A"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Culture" title="Culture" id="mwB3E">Human cultures</a> have developed many views of the planet.<sup about="#mwt1468" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20181224b_284-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20181224b"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NYT-20181224b-284"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-NYT-20181224b-284" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 272;" id="mwB3I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3M">[272]</span></a></sup> The standard <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Astronomical_symbols" title="Astronomical symbols" id="mwB3Q">astronomical symbols</a> of Earth are a quartered circle, <span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File" data-mw='{"caption":"ðŸœ¨"}' id="mwB3U"><a href="./File:Earth_symbol_(fixed_width).svg" class="mw-file-description" title="ðŸœ¨" id="mwB3Y"><img alt="ðŸœ¨" resource="./File:Earth_symbol_(fixed_width).svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg/15px-Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="15" data-file-height="15" data-file-type="drawing" height="15" width="15" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg/23px-Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg/30px-Earth_symbol_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwB3c"/></a></span>,<sup about="#mwt1469" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-liungman2004_285-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"liungman2004"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-liungman2004-285" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 273;" id="mwB3g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3k">[273]</span></a></sup> representing the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Four_corners_of_the_world" title="Four corners of the world" id="mwB3o">four corners of the world</a>, and a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Globus_cruciger" title="Globus cruciger" id="mwB3s">globus cruciger</a>, <span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File" data-mw='{"caption":"â™"}' id="mwB3w"><a href="./File:Globus_cruciger_(fixed_width).svg" class="mw-file-description" title="â™" id="mwB30"><img alt="â™" resource="./File:Globus_cruciger_(fixed_width).svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg/15px-Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="15" data-file-height="15" data-file-type="drawing" height="15" width="15" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg/23px-Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg/30px-Globus_cruciger_%28fixed_width%29.svg.png 2x" class="mw-file-element" id="mwB34"/></a></span>. Earth is sometimes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Personification" title="Personification" id="mwB38">personified</a> as a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deity" title="Deity" id="mwB4A">deity</a>. In many cultures it is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mother_goddess" title="Mother goddess" id="mwB4E">mother goddess</a> that is also the primary <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fertility_deity" title="Fertility deity" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB4I">fertility deity</a>.<sup about="#mwt1473" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Stookey-2004_286-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Stookey-2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Stookey-2004-286"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Stookey-2004-286" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 274;" id="mwB4M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4Q">[274]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Creation_myth" title="Creation myth" id="mwB4U">Creation myths</a> in many religions involve the creation of Earth by a supernatural deity or deities.<sup about="#mwt1474" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Stookey-2004_286-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Stookey-2004"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-Stookey-2004-286" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 274;" id="mwB4Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4c">[274]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gaia_hypothesis" title="Gaia hypothesis" id="mwB4g">Gaia hypothesis</a>, developed in the mid-20th century, compared Earth's environments and life as a single self-regulating organism leading to broad stabilization of the conditions of habitability.<sup about="#mwt1478" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-287" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-287"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-287" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 275;" id="mwB4k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4o">[275]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1482" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-288" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-288"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-288" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 276;" id="mwB4s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4w">[276]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1486" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-289" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-289"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-289" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 277;" id="mwB40"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB44">[277]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB48"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Timeline_of_first_images_of_Earth_from_space" title="Timeline of first images of Earth from space" id="mwB5A">Images of Earth taken from space</a>, particularly during the Apollo program, have been credited with altering the way that people viewed the planet that they lived on, called the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Overview_effect" title="Overview effect" id="mwB5E">overview effect</a>, emphasizing its beauty, uniqueness and apparent fragility.<sup about="#mwt1495" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-290" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-290"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-290" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 278;" id="mwB5I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5M">[278]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1500" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-291" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-291"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-291" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 279;" id="mwB5Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5U">[279]</span></a></sup> In particular, this caused a realization of the scope of effects from human activity on Earth's environment. Enabled by science, particularly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_observation" title="Earth observation" id="mwB5Y">Earth observation</a>,<sup about="#mwt1504" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-292" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-292"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-292" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 280;" id="mwB5c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5g">[280]</span></a></sup> humans have started to take <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism" id="mwB5k">action on environmental issues</a> globally,<sup about="#mwt1508" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-293" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-293"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-293" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 281;" id="mwB5o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5s">[281]</span></a></sup> acknowledging the impact of humans and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecological_network" title="Ecological network" id="mwB5w">interconnectedness of Earth's environments</a>.</p>

<p id="mwB50">Scientific investigation has resulted in several culturally transformative shifts in people's view of the planet. Initial belief in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flat_Earth" title="Flat Earth" id="mwB54">flat Earth</a> was gradually displaced in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece" id="mwB58">Ancient Greece</a> by the idea of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spherical_Earth" title="Spherical Earth" id="mwB6A">spherical Earth</a>, which was attributed to both the philosophers <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pythagoras" title="Pythagoras" id="mwB6E">Pythagoras</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parmenides" title="Parmenides" id="mwB6I">Parmenides</a>.<sup about="#mwt1515" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-294" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-294"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-294" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 282;" id="mwB6M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6Q">[282]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1519" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-295" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-295"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-295" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 283;" id="mwB6U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6Y">[283]</span></a></sup> Earth was generally believed to be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geocentric_model" title="Geocentric model" id="mwB6c">the center of the universe</a> until the 16th century, when scientists first concluded that it was <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism" id="mwB6g">a moving object</a>, one of the planets of the Solar System.<sup about="#mwt1520" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-arnett20060716_296-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"arnett20060716"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-arnett20060716-296" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 284;" id="mwB6k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6o">[284]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB6s">It was only during the 19th century that geologists realized <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth's_age" title="Earth's age" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB6w">Earth's age</a> was at least many millions of years.<sup about="#mwt1527" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-297" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-297"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-297" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 285;" id="mwB60"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB64">[285]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lord_Kelvin" title="Lord Kelvin" id="mwB68">Lord Kelvin</a> used <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermodynamics" title="Thermodynamics" id="mwB7A">thermodynamics</a> to estimate the age of Earth to be between 20 million and 400<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB7E">Â </span>million years in 1864, sparking a vigorous debate on the subject; it was only when radioactivity and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating" id="mwB7I">radioactive dating</a> were discovered in the late 19th and early 20th centuries that a reliable mechanism for determining Earth's age was established, proving the planet to be billions of years old.<sup about="#mwt1531" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-298" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-298"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-298" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 286;" id="mwB7M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB7Q">[286]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1535" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-299" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-299"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-299" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 287;" id="mwB7U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB7Y">[287]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="32" id="mwB7c"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="33" id="mwB7o"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2>
<!--
 List alphabetized. Please keep it that way, thank you!
-->
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1547" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"reflist ","href":"./Template:Reflist"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30em "},"group":{"wt":"\"n\""},"refs":{"wt":"&lt;ref name=\"Aoki\">The ultimate source of these figures, uses the term \"seconds of UT1\" instead of \"seconds of mean solar time\".â€”{{cite journal |last1=Aoki |first1=S. |title=The new definition of universal time |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |year=1982 |volume=105 |issue=2 |pages=359â€“361 |bibcode=1982A&amp;A...105..359A |last2=Kinoshita |first2=H. |last3=Guinot |first3=B. |last4=Kaplan |first4=G. H. |last5=McCarthy |first5=D. D. |last6=Seidelmann |first6=P. K.}}&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"apsis\">aphelion = &apos;&apos;a&apos;&apos; Ã— (1 + &apos;&apos;e&apos;&apos;); perihelion = &apos;&apos;a&apos;&apos; Ã— (1&amp;nbsp;â€“ &apos;&apos;e&apos;&apos;), where &apos;&apos;a&apos;&apos; is the semi-major axis and &apos;&apos;e&apos;&apos; is the eccentricity. The difference between Earth&apos;s perihelion and aphelion is 5 million kilometers.â€”{{cite book|page=144|title=Probing the New Solar System|last1=Wilkinson|first1=John|year= 2009|publisher=CSIRO Publishing|isbn=978-0-643-09949-4}}&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"epoch\">All astronomical quantities vary, both [[Secular phenomena|secularly]] and [[Frequency|periodically]]. The quantities given are the values at the instant [[J2000.0]] of the secular variation, ignoring all periodic variations.&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"hill_radius\">For Earth, the [[Hill radius]] is &lt;math>R_H = a\\left ( \\frac{m}{3M} \\right )^{\\frac{1}{3}}&lt;/math>, where &apos;&apos;m&apos;&apos; is the mass of Earth, &apos;&apos;a&apos;&apos; is an astronomical unit, and &apos;&apos;M&apos;&apos; is the mass of the Sun. So the radius in AU is about &lt;math>\\left ( \\frac{1}{3 \\cdot 332,946} \\right )^{\\frac{1}{3}} = 0.01&lt;/math>.&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"jaes41_3_379\">Including the [[Somali Plate]], which is being formed out of the African Plate. See: {{cite journal |first=Jean |last=Chorowicz |date=October 2005 |title=The East African rift system |journal=[[Journal of African Earth Sciences]] |volume=43 |issue=1â€“3 |pages=379â€“410 |doi=10.1016/j.jafrearsci.2005.07.019 |bibcode=2005JAfES..43..379C}}&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"solar_energy\">Aphelion is 103.4% of the distance to perihelion. Due to the inverse square law, the radiation at perihelion is about 106.9% of the energy at aphelion.&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"surfacecover\">Due to natural fluctuations, ambiguities surrounding [[Ice shelf|ice shelves]], and mapping conventions for [[vertical datum]]s, exact values for land and ocean coverage are not meaningful. Based on data from the [[Vector Map]] and [http://www.landcover.org/ Global Landcover] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150326085837/http://www.landcover.org/ |date=26 March 2015}} datasets, extreme values for coverage of lakes and streams are 0.6% and 1.0% of Earth&apos;s surface. The ice sheets of [[Antarctica]] and [[Greenland]] are counted as land, even though much of the rock that supports them lies below sea level.&lt;/ref>\n\n&lt;ref name=\"space_debris\">As of 4 January 2018, the United States Strategic Command tracked a total of 18,835 artificial objects, mostly debris. See: {{cite journal |url=https://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/quarterly-news/pdfs/odqnv22i1.pdf |title=Satellite Box Score |journal=Orbital Debris Quarterly News |editor1-first=Phillip |editor1-last=Anz-Meador |editor2-first=Debi |editor2-last=Shoots |volume=22 |issue=1 |page=12 |date=February 2018 |access-date=18 April 2018}}&lt;/ref>"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB7s">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width  " style="column-width: 30em ;" about="#mwt1547" id="mwB7w">

about="#cite_note-epoch-1" id="cite_note-epoch-1"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-epoch_1-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB74"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB78">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-epoch-1" class="mw-reference-text">All astronomical quantities vary, both <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Secular_phenomena" title="Secular phenomena" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB8A">secularly</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Frequency" title="Frequency" id="mwB8E">periodically</a>. The quantities given are the values at the instant <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./J2000.0" title="J2000.0" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB8I">J2000.0</a> of the secular variation, ignoring all periodic variations.</span></li><li about="#cite_note-apsis-2" id="cite_note-apsis-2"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-apsis_2-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB8M"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB8Q">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-apsis-2" class="mw-reference-text">aphelion = <i id="mwB8U">a</i> Ã— (1 + <i id="mwB8Y">e</i>); perihelion = <i id="mwB8c">a</i> Ã— (1<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB8g">Â </span>â€“ <i id="mwB8k">e</i>), where <i id="mwB8o">a</i> is the semi-major axis and <i id="mwB8s">e</i> is the eccentricity. The difference between Earth's perihelion and aphelion is 5 million kilometers.â€”<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1133582631" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" about="#mwt1565" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Module:Citation/CS1/styles.css"},"body":{"extsrc":""}}' id="mwB8w">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite id="CITEREFWilkinson2009" class="citation book cs1">Wilkinson, John (2009). <i id="mwB80">Probing the New Solar System</i>. CSIRO Publishing. p.<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB84">Â </span>144. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB88">ISBN</a><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Probing+the+New+Solar+System&amp;rft.pages=144&amp;rft.pub=CSIRO+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-643-09949-4&amp;rft.aulast=Wilkinson&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988" id="mwB9M"></span></span></li><li about="#cite_note-circ-14" id="cite_note-circ-14"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-circ_14-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB9Q"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB9U">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-circ-14" class="mw-reference-text">Earth's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Circumference" title="Circumference" id="mwB9Y">circumference</a> is almost exactly 40,000<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB9c">Â </span>km because the meter was calibrated on this measurementâ€”more specifically, 1/10-millionth of the distance between the poles and the equator.</span></li><li about="#cite_note-surfacecover-16" id="cite_note-surfacecover-16"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-surfacecover_16-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB9g"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB9k">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-surfacecover-16" class="mw-reference-text">Due to natural fluctuations, ambiguities surrounding <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ice_shelf" title="Ice shelf" id="mwB9o">ice shelves</a>, and mapping conventions for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertical_datum" title="Vertical datum" id="mwB9s">vertical datums</a>, exact values for land and ocean coverage are not meaningful. Based on data from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vector_Map" title="Vector Map" id="mwB9w">Vector Map</a> and <a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="http://www.landcover.org/" class="external text" id="mwB90">Global Landcover</a> <a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150326085837/http://www.landcover.org/" class="external text" id="mwB94">Archived</a> 26 March 2015 at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine" id="mwB98">Wayback Machine</a><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Webarchive_template_wayback_links" id="mwB-A"/> datasets, extreme values for coverage of lakes and streams are 0.6% and 1.0% of Earth's surface. The ice sheets of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwB-E">Antarctica</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenland" title="Greenland" id="mwB-I">Greenland</a> are counted as land, even though much of the rock that supports them lies below sea level.</span></li><li about="#cite_note-93" id="cite_note-93"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-93" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB-M"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB-Q">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-93" class="mw-reference-text"> If Earth were shrunk to the size of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Billiard_ball" title="Billiard ball" id="mwB-U">billiard ball</a>, some areas of Earth such as large mountain ranges and oceanic trenches would feel like tiny imperfections, whereas much of the planet, including the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Great_Plains" title="Great Plains" id="mwB-Y">Great Plains</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abyssal_plain" title="Abyssal plain" id="mwB-c">abyssal plains</a>, would feel smoother.<sup about="#mwt521" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-92" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-92"}}'><a href="./Earth#cite_note-92" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 88;" id="mwB-g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-k">[88]</span></a></sup></span></li><li about="#cite_note-jaes41_3_379-123" id="cite_note-jaes41_3_379-123"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-jaes41_3_379_123-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwB-o"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwB-s">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-jaes41_3_379-123" class="mw-reference-text">Including the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Somali_Plate" title="Somali Plate" id="mwB-w">Somali Plate</a>, which is being formed out of the African Plate.     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="mwCCY">{\displaystyle R_{H}=a\left({\frac {m}{3M}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}}</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/596f8baf206a81478afd4194b44138715dc1a05c" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -2.005ex; width:16.736ex; height:6.009ex;" alt="R_{H}=a\left({\frac {m}{3M}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}" id="mwCCc"/></span>, where <i id="mwCCg">m</i> is the mass of Earth, <i id="mwCCk">a</i> is an astronomical unit, and <i id="mwCCo">M</i> is the mass of the Sun. So the radius in AU is about <span class="mwe-math-element" typeof="mw:Extension/math" about="#mwt1571" data-mw='{"name":"math","attrs":{},"body":{"extsrc":"\\left ( \\frac{1}{3 \\cdot 332,946} \\right )^{\\frac{1}{3}} = 0.01"}}' id="mwCCs"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;" id="mwCCw"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01}" id="mwCC0">
  <semantics id="mwCC4">
    <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD" id="mwCC8">
      <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0" id="mwCDA">
        <msup id="mwCDE">
          <mrow id="mwCDI">
            <mo id="mwCDM">(</mo>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD" id="mwCDQ">
              <mfrac id="mwCDU">
                <mn id="mwCDY">1</mn>
                <mrow id="mwCDc">
                  <mn id="mwCDg">3</mn>
                  <mo id="mwCDk">â‹…<!-- â‹… --></mo>
                  <mn id="mwCDo">332</mn>
                  <mo id="mwCDs">,</mo>
                  <mn id="mwCDw">946</mn>
                </mrow>
              </mfrac>
            </mrow>
            <mo id="mwCD0">)</mo>
          </mrow>
          <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD" id="mwCD4">
            <mfrac id="mwCD8">
              <mn id="mwCEA">1</mn>
              <mn id="mwCEE">3</mn>
            </mfrac>
          </mrow>
        </msup>
        <mo id="mwCEI">=</mo>
        <mn id="mwCEM">0.01</mn>
      </mstyle>
    </mrow>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="mwCEQ">{\displaystyle \left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01}</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7ab5412b4744a2163206868fe8ec2726455c4785" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -2.505ex; width:24.076ex; height:7.176ex;" alt="\left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01" id="mwCEU"/></span>.</span></li><li about="#cite_note-solar_energy-179" id="cite_note-solar_energy-179"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-solar_energy_179-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwCEY"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwCEc">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-solar_energy-179" class="mw-reference-text">Aphelion is 103.4% of the distance to perihelion. Due to the inverse square law, the radiation at perihelion is about 106.9% of the energy at aphelion.</span></li><li about="#cite_note-space_debris-198" id="cite_note-space_debris-198"><a href="./Earth#cite_ref-space_debris_198-0" data-mw-group="n" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwCEg"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwCEk">â†‘ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-space_debris-198" class="mw-reference-text">As of 4 January 2018, the United States Strategic Command tracked a total of 18,835 artificial objects, mostly debris. See: <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631" about="#mwt1582" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Module:Citation/CS1/styles.css"},"body":{"extsrc":""}}' id="mwCEo"/><cite id="CITEREFAnz-MeadorShoots2018" class="citation journal cs1">Anz-Meador, Phillip; Shoots, Debi, eds. (February 2018). <a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/quarterly-news/pdfs/odqnv22i1.pdf" class="external text" id="mwCEs">"Satellite Box Score"</a> <span class="cs1-format" id="mwCEw">(PDF)</span>. <i id="mwCE0">Orbital Debris Quarterly News</i>. <b id="mwCE4">22</b> (1): 12<span class="reference-accessdate" id="mwCE8">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap" id="mwCFA">18 April</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Orbital+Debris+Quarterly+News&amp;rft.atitle=Satellite+Box+Score&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=12&amp;rft.date=2018-02&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Forbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov%2Fquarterly-news%2Fpdfs%2Fodqnv22i1.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988" id="mwCFE"></span></span></li></ol></div>

typeof="mw:File/Frameless mw:Extension/imagemap" about="#mwt2340" data-mw='{"name":"imagemap","attrs":{},"body":{"extsrc":"\nFile:Solar System true color banner version.jpg|frameless|center|upright=3\n#The Sun\nrect 0 0 450 567 [[Sun|The Sun]]\n#Mercury\ncircle 500 284 60 [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]\n#Venus\ncircle 700 284 60 [[Venus]]\n#Earth and the Moon\ncircle 850 300 30 [[Moon|The Moon]]\ncircle 900 284 60 [[Earth]]\n#Mars\ncircle 1050 284 60 [[Mars]]\n#Jupiter and satellites\ncircle 1650 284 250 [[Jupiter]]\ncircle 1300 284 100 [[Moons of Jupiter]]\n#Saturn and satellites\n# - by placing the rectangle code for the Rings of Saturn AFTER Saturn, Saturn is \"on top\" (and can co-exist)\ncircle 2600 284 230 [[Saturn]]\ncircle 2050 284 80 [[Moons of Saturn]]\nrect 2100 250 3100 330 [[Rings of Saturn]]\n#Uranus and satellites\ncircle 3250 284 100 [[Uranus]]\ncircle 3275 420 60 [[Moons of Uranus]]\n#Neptune and satellites\ncircle 3600 284 100 [[Neptune]]\ncircle 3500 320 60 [[Moons of Neptune]]\n\ndesc none\n# - setting this to \"bottom-right\" will display a (rather large) icon linking to the graphic, if desired\n\n#Notes:\n#Details on the new coding for clickable images is here: [http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:ImageMap]\n#The smaller planets have a bit of an overlap just to ensure they&apos;re locatable, especially in the belts.\n#While it may look strange, it&apos;s important to keep the codes for a particular system in order. The clickable coding treats the first object created in an area as the one on top.\n# - I&apos;ve placed moons on \"top\" so that their smaller circles won&apos;t disappear \"under\" their respective planets or dwarf planets.\n#The \"poly\" code would be more appropriate for the moons of Jupiter, Saturn, and Uranus. However, there appears to be a bug with that aspect of the code.\n# - I&apos;ve compensated by using oversized circles for those moon groups, and tucking them UNDER their planets for now.\n#The Sun is a rectangle as that approximates the edge closely enough for the purposes of this template.\n#I&apos;ve guessed as to the boundaries for the KB, SD, and OC - if they need adjustment, load the image into Paint and use the pencil tool to find the appropriate coordinates.\n"}}' id="mwFgs"><span id="mwFgw"><img resource="./File:Solar_System_true_color_banner_version.jpg" 284 100 [[Neptune]]\ncircle 3500 320 60 [[Moons of Neptune]]\n\ndesc none\n# - setting this to \"bottom-right\" will display a (rather large) icon linking to the graphic, if desired\n\n#Notes:\n#Details on the new coding for clickable images is here: [http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:ImageMap]\n#The smaller planets have a bit of an overlap just to ensure they&apos;re locatable, especially in the belts.\n#While it may look strange, it&apos;s important to keep the codes for a particular system in order. The clickable coding treats the first object created in an area as the one on top.\n# - I&apos;ve placed moons on \"top\" so that their smaller circles won&apos;t disappear \"under\" their respective planets or dwarf planets.\n#The \"poly\" code would be more appropriate for the moons of Jupiter, Saturn, and Uranus. However, there appears to be a bug with that aspect of the code.\n# - I&apos;ve compensated by using oversized circles for those moon groups, and tucking them UNDER their planets for now.\n#The Sun is a rectangle as that approximates the edge closely enough for the purposes of this template.\n#I&apos;ve guessed as to the boundaries for the KB, SD, and OC - if they need adjustment, load the image </div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th id="Planets_anddwarfs" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:center;"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Planet" title="Planet">Planets</a> and<br/><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dwarf_planet" title="Dwarf planet">dwarfs</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
